title: Singapore’s key exports may shrink in 2025 amid US tariffs, trade war: Economists - (Published 17 hour(s), 30 minute(s) ago)
content: Singapore's trade agency said it is monitoring the tariff situation and will adjust its 2025 forecast as necessary. Read more at straitstimes.com. Read more at straitstimes.com.
resumen: Several economists have lowered their forecasts for Singapore’s key exports, expecting them to shrink in 2025 as the economy confronts the global trade chaos sparked by US President Donald Trump’s tariff barrage. Enterprise Singapore noted that it is “actively monitoring the evolving tariff situation and will adjust the Nodx forecast for 2025 as necessary to reflect the changing market conditions”. The trade agency had forecast in February that Nodx would rise by 1 per cent to 3 per cent in 2025, after eking out 0.2 per cent growth in 2024. Its latest data showed growth in key exports slowed in March ahead of Mr Trump’s April 2 announcement of global tariffs that triggered an escalating trade war with China. Shipments in March rose 5.4 per cent year on year, worse than expected and lower than the 7.5 per cent increase in February. Analysts polled by Reuters had forecast growth of 14.1 per cent. Electronics exports expanded 11.9 per cent year on year. Non-electronics exports grew 3.8 per cent – half the pace of February’s revised 7.7 per cent increase. Non-monetary gold led the charge with a 64.7 per cent expansion, while pharmaceuticals rose by 24.9 per cent. Nodx to Taiwan, Indonesia and South Korea grew, though shipments to China – Singapore’s single largest export market – declined. The main drag on Nodx was China, which saw a 29.4 per cent drop in shipments versus a 27.4 per cent plunge in February. Maybank Research senior economist Chua Hak Bin said the decline in exports to China suggests that US tariffs are disrupting Chinese demand and manufacturing supply chains. Shipments to the US grew 5.7 per cent in March, a sharp drop from the 21.5 per cent growth in February. Exports to Taiwan rose by 45.7 per cent in March, following the 77.9 per cent expansion the month before. Shipments to Indonesia expanded by 63 per cent in March, after the 5.4 per cent decline in the month earlier. Nodx to South Korea rose by 21.6 per cent in March, after the 31.4 per cent growth in the preceding month. Compared with a year earlier, total trade rose 3.4 per cent in March, following a 4.6 per cent expansion in February. DBS Bank senior economist Chua Han Teng said any downward revision of Enterprise SG’s export forecasts should align with the weaker 2025 gross domestic product (GDP) growth outlook. The World Trade Organisation (WTO) has already slashed its 2025 forecast for the volume of global trade in goods due to the sweeping tariffs, ensuing retaliation and uncertainty. The WTO now expects world merchandise trade volume to contract by 0.2 per cent instead of expanding by 2.7 per cent as in its January forecast. The Ministry of Trade and Industry on April 14 lowered its forecast for full-year 2025 GDP to a range of zero per cent to 2 per cent, from 1 per cent to 3 per cent previously. Mr Barnabas Gan, group chief economist at RHB Bank, lowered his full-year growth forecast to zero per cent, with downside risks, from 2 per cent. OCBC Bank chief economist Selena Ling cut her 2025 Nodx forecast to a range of minus 1 per cent to 1 per cent, down from a previous forecast of 2 per cent to 4 per cent.

title: Wisconsin will suffer more from Trump tariffs than Minnesota. Here's why. | Opinion - (Published 21 hour(s), 28 minute(s) ago)
content: Wisconsin is far more exposed to the risks of Trump’s tariffs than Minnesota, which traces to how each state responded to the decline of manufacturing ...
resumen:
Wisconsin will suffer more from Trump tariffs than Minnesota.

Wisconsin and Minnesota, historically similar, diverged economically starting in the 1980s.

Minnesota diversified its economy into tech, healthcare, and finance, while Wisconsin remained largely focused on traditional manufacturing.

This difference in approach has left Wisconsin more vulnerable to trade tensions and tariffs.

Trump first term tariffs disproportionately impacted Wisconsin industries like dairy and manufacturing.

In the 1980s, deindustrialization hit both states hard.

Minnesota's response was forward-looking: it diversified.

State leaders invested in education, healthcare, and tech infrastructure.

The University of Minnesota partnered with private companies to commercialize medical research, helping spawn a booming medtech sector.

Medtronic grew into a global giant headquartered in Minneapolis.

3M pivoted from sandpaper and adhesives to electronics, healthcare, and safety products.

The Mayo Clinic expanded its role as a global leader in healthcare.

Minnesota’s Twin Cities cultivated a finance and insurance sector that now includes giants like U.S. Bank and Ameriprise Financial.

Wisconsin, on the other hand, largely doubled down on traditional manufacturing.

Milwaukee remained reliant on companies like Harley-Davidson, while Kohler continued producing plumbing fixtures from its headquarters in Sheboygan.

In the 1990s, as NAFTA and globalization ramped up, Minnesota's economic transition began to pay off.

Wisconsin exports remain rooted in bulk commodities.

When factories in towns like Janesville and Fond du Lac shut down, laid-off workers had few high-tech job options waiting nearby.

His trade war with China led to retaliatory tariffs that slammed Wisconsin dairy farms.

China, once a top buyer of Wisconsin ginseng and soybeans, sharply cut imports.

Harley-Davidson found itself caught between tariffs on steel and European retaliations, prompting it to shift some production overseas.

Trump has now proposed a 10% blanket tariff on all imports, along with steeper penalties for countries like China.

A company like Briggs & Stratton, which makes small engines in Wauwatosa, depends on a global supply chain.

Minnesota, by contrast, is better insulated.

An analysis by the New York Times shows that retaliatory tariffs imposed by the European Union and others are concentrated in industries that account for nearly 10% of Wisconsin’s workforce.

The same tariffs impact 6% of Minnesota’s workforce.

Luke Fuszard is a lecturer in the Department of Political Science at the University of Wisconsin-Madison and a Senior Fellow at the High Road Strategy Center.

title: He Planned Trump’s Tariffs the First Time. Here’s What He Thinks of the New Ones. - (Published 14 hour(s), 35 minute(s) ago)
content: Your gadgets might have gotten pricier. Your stocks might have tanked. But Wilbur Ross says it’s all a part of the plan.
resumen: Wilbur Ross, former commerce secretary during Trump’s first term, spearheaded the beginning of Trump’s long-term trade war, providing the groundwork for new tariffs on certain sectors (steel and aluminum) and against certain nations (China). Ross has been happy to defend Trump’s current trade policy to the media, dismissing fears of recession or foreign aggravation while insisting that the U.S. can win any trade war. Ross believes Trump is fine-tuning the broad brush he used in the beginning and is starting to deal with the logical exceptions that should be made. Ross thinks it’s a natural process. Ross believes Trump has concluded to take a very firm stand on China, and probably end up with them having much more punitive tariffs than other countries. Ross said the first administration was devoting a lot of time to figuring out what were the actual powers the president can use without going back to Congress. Ross said the steel and aluminum tariffs that he had provided the material for were litigated up to the Supreme Court. Ross said the state of California already has said it will bring litigation on some of the tariffs. Ross said the CHIPS Act provides all sorts of incentives to some of these same companies. Ross said he thinks [Trump] views, longer term, the tariffs as another mechanism also for helping them. Ross said the Biden administration had a sensible trade policy with China. Ross said the Biden administration’s most recent edicts on semiconductors basically prevented companies like Applied Materials and Lam Research from selling chips to China, but they didn’t do anything about the subcomponents of those advanced chips, for example, ceramics from Japan. Ross said he doesn’t think there’s the potential for many companies, both domestic and international, to view all this back-and-forth and end up more reluctant to build factories or invest here in the long term. Ross said he was a keynote speaker at an annual semiconductor industry meeting. Ross said the executives are all concerned, but they all understand why the endgame is what it really has to be. Ross said they would like to be patriotic, and their only concern is to make sure that the loopholes get closed. Ross said he absolutely does believe that the way Trump is imposing tariffs now will be conducive to bringing back manufacturing to the States, for gadgets, electronics, artificial intelligence. Ross said once Trump makes a deal with the first couple of big players, whether that’s Japan or Vietnam or whomever, he thinks then people will see there’s a path forward and he thinks markets will settle down. Ross said he thinks if they make it clear that you need to do this in order to get relief, then you could actually end up, longer term, with lower tariffs and lower nontariff trade values, not higher. Ross said there were plenty of nuances that all of them had. Ross said there’s only one person who’s elected president—that’s Trump. Ross said at the end of the day, it’s his view that it’s his call.

title: Global trade takes a hit from Trump’s tariffs - (Published 22 hour(s), 10 minute(s) ago)
content: Forecasts from major international organizations warn of the impact of the US president’s economic policies on the exchange of goods ...
resumen:
Economic forecasts are attempting to put figures to the sense of anxiety the global economy is experiencing following Donald Trump’s crackdown on trade. The U.S. president’s aggressive tariff policy threatens to curb international trade, hinder economic growth, and fragment the economy.

The World Trade Organization (WTO) estimates that merchandise trade will decline by 0.2% this year due to new U.S. tariffs. The WTO, chaired by Nigerian President Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, published its new forecasts for world trade on Wednesday. The new estimate for 2025 is almost three percentage points lower than what it would have been without the recent changes. Okonjo-Iweala warned that the trade war between the U.S. and China risks dragging the world into a recession. She expressed concern about economic and geopolitical fragmentation, with a growing dissociation between Washington and Beijing that forces other countries to take one side or the other. If that happens, global production could fall by 7%.

World Bank President Ajay Banga warned this Wednesday that increased uncertainty and economic instability will weigh on the global economy. The head of the World Bank argued that trade tensions are causing economic agents to become more cautious, which could curb investment and purchasing decisions by businesses and households. Banga calls on countries to “sit down and negotiate as soon as possible to establish a dialogue on trade issues.”

The IMF also joined the chorus of voices warning this week about the impact of tariffs on global trade. The organization, chaired by Bulgarian President Kristalina Georgieva, is finalizing preparations for its major annual meeting in Washington. The report published this week by the Fund states that geopolitical risk could manifest itself in the form of trade tensions, such as tariffs, trade wars, and sanctions, could be imposed for geopolitical reasons and affect international relations and economic activity.

This economic instability will very likely lead the European Central Bank (ECB) to cut interest rates by a quarter of a point this Thursday, to 2.25%. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell is advocating caution in these uncertain times. Powell emphasized the inflationary risks of tariffs and expressed his support for waiting for greater clarity on Trump’s erratic policies before deciding on the price of money. The level of the tariff increases announced so far is significantly larger than anticipated. The same is likely to be true of the economic effects, which will include higher inflation and slower growth. Both survey- and market-based measures of near-term inflation expectations have moved up significantly, with survey participants pointing to tariffs. The U.S. economy was growing strongly, with very low unemployment and inflation almost under control, but now uncertainty and instability are the dominant tone in the face of Trump’s chaotic measures and his constant rectifications and band-aids. Powell acknowledged Wednesday that the economy is “moving away” from both objectives. For now, he prefers to wait and see.

Peterson Institute economists David H. Feldman and Gary Clyde Hufbauer warn that Trump’s tariff drift “may be able to bully small nations that depend on us, but in the international power game the European Union, China, and Japan will push back with bad consequences for America. We risk reigniting the kind of zero-sum international trade aggression that characterized the period between the First and Second World Wars, a time when militarism led to a global cataclysm.”

title: Trump says he ‘couldn’t care less’ if foreign automakers raise prices due to tariffs - (Published Apr 17, 2025)
content: President Donald Trump told NBC News in an interview ... Until that time, USMCA-compliant auto parts will remain tariff-free. The president also said the tariffs would be permanent.
resumen:
En una entrevista telefónica con NBC News, el presidente Donald Trump dijo que no despediría a nadie involucrado en el chat grupal de Signal en el que se divulgaron inadvertidamente planes de ataque militar a un periodista y agregó que "no podría importarle menos" si los fabricantes de automóviles aumentaban los precios debido a los nuevos aranceles.

Trump dijo que "no podría importarle menos" si los fabricantes de automóviles aumentaban los precios después de anunciar que impondría aranceles del 25% a todos los automóviles de fabricación extranjera.

Trump dijo: "El mensaje es felicitaciones, si fabricas tu automóvil en los Estados Unidos, vas a ganar mucho dinero. Si no lo haces, probablemente tendrás que venir a los Estados Unidos, porque si fabricas tu automóvil en los Estados Unidos, no hay arancel".

Cuando se le preguntó si les dijo a los directores ejecutivos que no subieran los precios, como informó The Wall Street Journal, Trump agregó: "No, nunca dije eso. No podría importarme menos si suben los precios, porque la gente va a empezar a comprar coches fabricados en Estados Unidos".

Trump continuó: "No podría importarme menos. Espero que suban sus precios, porque si lo hacen, la gente comprará coches fabricados en Estados Unidos. Tenemos muchos".

Cuando se le preguntó si le preocupaba que subieran los precios de los automóviles, Trump dijo: "No, no podría importarme menos, porque si suben los precios de los automóviles extranjeros, comprarán automóviles estadounidenses".

Después de la entrevista, un asistente se puso en contacto con NBC News para decir que Trump se refería específicamente a los precios de los automóviles extranjeros.

NBC News informó esta semana que las autopartes extranjeras también serían gravadas con un 25% incluso si los vehículos en los que se instalan se ensamblan en el país.

Las empresas que importan vehículos en virtud del Acuerdo Estados Unidos-México-Canadá (USMCA) recibirán una consideración especial hasta que el gobierno establezca un proceso para cobrar los derechos del 25%, según la Casa Blanca.

Hasta ese momento, las autopartes que cumplen con el USMCA permanecerán libres de aranceles.

El presidente también dijo que los aranceles serían permanentes.

Trump dijo: "Absolutamente, son permanentes, claro. El mundo ha estado estafando a los Estados Unidos durante los últimos 40 años y más. Y todo lo que estamos haciendo es ser justos y, francamente, estoy siendo muy generoso".

El anuncio de los aranceles de Trump el miércoles se produjo pocas semanas antes de su "Día de la Liberación" previsto para el 2 de abril, cuando los aranceles sobre una variedad de bienes de consumo entrarán en vigor.

Trump dijo que no planea retrasar aún más la imposición de los aranceles del 2 de abril, y consideraría negociar sobre ese punto "solo si la gente está dispuesta a darnos algo de gran valor. Porque los países tienen cosas de gran valor, de lo contrario, no hay lugar para la negociación".

Trump dijo que no tiene planes de despedir a nadie después de la noticia de que el asesor de seguridad nacional Michael Waltz agregó a un periodista a un chat grupal de la aplicación Signal con miembros de alto rango de la administración Trump que estaban discutiendo planes para atacar a los militantes hutíes en Yemen a principios de este mes.

Trump dijo: "No despido a la gente por noticias falsas y por cacerías de brujas", calificando la historia de "noticias falsas" durante toda la entrevista.

Trump dijo que todavía confía en Waltz y en el secretario de Defensa Pete Hegseth, quien también estaba en el chat de Signal y envió una línea de tiempo detallada de los ataques planeados antes de que ocurrieran.

Trump agregó: "Creo que es solo una cacería de brujas y las noticias falsas, como ustedes, hablan de eso todo el tiempo, pero es solo una cacería de brujas, y no debería hablarse de eso. title: Fed chairman Jerome Powell warns of tariff strife as President Trump seeks lower interest rates - (Published 11 hour(s), 43 minute(s) ago)
content: President Donald Trump can't wait for Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell's "termination," after Chicago speech. Here's what's happening.
resumen: Trump calls for a decrease in interest rates as the Fed looks at what might need to happen to combat inflation. The next Fed meeting to discuss interest rates isn't until May. Trump looks forward to Powell's "termination" after Fed chairman warns of inflation as price changes occur due to tariffs. Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell and President Donald Trump are at odds over interest rates. One of the main issues of whether rates should be cut or not is Trump's tariffs. In remarks during an April 16 event, Powell stated that there was need for "greater clarity" on the on again, off again tariffs that has led to much worry among financial giants and Americans on whether or not they could lead the United States to a recession. "Unemployment is likely to go up as the economy slows, in all likelihood, and inflation is likely to go up as tariffs find their way and some part of those tariffs come to be paid by the public," Powell said April 16, in remarks to the Economic Club of Chicago. The remark may cost Powell his position if Trump has his way. Along with Powell's warning of what the tariffs could potentially mean for the public, he also said the Fed should be focusing on fighting inflation, which could mean a delay in interest cuts. In a post on Truth Social on Thursday, April 17, Trump criticized Powell as "too late" when making decisions, the remarks he made about Trump's beloved tariffs and the Fed not lowering interest rates. At the end, he calls for Powell's termination. "...(Powell) should have lowered Interest Rates, like the ECB, long ago, but he should certainly lower them now. Powell’s termination cannot come fast enough!" the president wrote early Thursday morning. During the Economic Club meeting, Powell stated that politics is not what the Fed looks at when making its decisions on interest rates. "People can say whatever they want," Powell added. "That's fine. That's not a problem. But we will do what we do strictly without consideration of political or any other extraneous factors." The Fed is the organization in charge of cutting or hiking up interest rates in the United States. Usually rates are cut to help stimulate a flagging economy and job market. They raise interest rates to help combat rising costs and inflation. Legally, no. Trump cannot fire Powell from his position. The Fed's independence is something that is part of congressional law. So unless Congress changes the law, Powell's job is safe. "So, you know, Congress could change that law. But, I don't think there's any danger of that," Powell said. "Fed independence has pretty broad support across both political parties and both sides of the Hill." Powel was appointed chair of the Fed in 2018 during Trump's first administration. He was reappointed for a four-year term in 2022. In general, one way to curtail inflation rates is by hiking up interest rates in hopes of balancing out, but by doing that there are a number of economic risks that could follow, including an increase in unemployment. The Federal Reserve has yet to raise interest rates, and in March announced that they will remain steady for now. CME FedWatch site, which monitors the Federal Reserve and estimates possible rate increases, shows around a 91% chance that the Federal Reserve will leave interest rates where they are at its next meeting in May, and only an 8.9% likelihood that interest rates will be eased.

title: WTO warns of 80% trade decline between US and China - (Published 17 hour(s), 44 minute(s) ago)
content: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has issued a stark warning, predicting that trade between the US and China could plummet by as much as 80%.
resumen: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has issued a warning, predicting that trade between the United States and China could plummet by as much as 80% this year due to escalating tariff tensions. Both countries are vital trading partners for South Africa. In its latest Global Trade Outlook and Statistics report, the WTO emphasizes that rising tariff conflicts could force countries into one of two increasingly isolated economic blocs. In 2024, total goods trade between South Africa and the US amounted to $20.5 billion, with South Africa exporting $14.7 billion and importing $5.8 billion. Bilateral trade between South Africa and China reached a record $34.18 billion in 2023, an increase from $1.34 billion in 2000. South Africa primarily exports mineral products to China. Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Lweala stressed that the growing trade tensions between the US and China could disrupt global supply chains and stifle worldwide economic growth. "We currently estimate that merchandise trade between the US and China will fall by 81% — a drop that would have reached 91% without recent exemptions for products like smartphones,” Okonjo-Lweala said. "If this leads to broader fragmentation of the global economy along geopolitical lines into two isolated blocs, our estimates suggest global real GDP could drop by nearly 7% in the long term,” she warned. title: What Bangladesh stands to gain from withdrawal of US sanctions on Russia - (Published 16 hour(s), 41 minute(s) ago)
content: While President Trump can ease most US sanctions on Russia as part of the Black Sea Deal, severe restrictions require Congress approval, and international sanctions need global cooperation. If enacted ...
resumen:
On April 18, 2025, The Business Standard published an analysis on what Bangladesh stands to gain from the withdrawal of US sanctions on Russia.

If the Black Sea ceasefire deal is enacted, it could resolve complex issues like Rooppur loan repayments for Bangladesh, as well as lower food, fertiliser, and fuel prices.

The Black Sea ceasefire would ease Bangladesh's trade with the warring nations, cutting freight costs. Fuel prices are expected to drop, dragging down LNG, coal, food, and fertiliser prices — saving foreign currency and boosting Bangladesh's economy.

The Kremlin demands a pause in Black Sea fighting, contingent on lifting sanctions on Rosselkhozbank and other financial institutions involved in global food trade, including fish and fertilisers, and reconnecting them to SWIFT. All restrictions on food, fertilisers, ships, and agricultural machinery must also be lifted.

Following Russia's invasion of Ukraine, the US and allies imposed extensive sanctions to hinder Moscow's war efforts. President Trump seeks to end the conflict. While Trump can lift most US sanctions independently, Congress approval is needed for the severest restrictions, and international sanctions require global cooperation.

Bangladesh imports several products from both Russia and Ukraine, such as crude oil, food grains, fertilisers, metals, and chemicals. If the ceasefire deal takes effect, prices of these products will decline.

The Kremlin put forward certain demands, including lifting US and EU sanctions on Russian institutions involved in trade, restoring their SWIFT access, and removing all restrictions on food, fertilisers, ships, and agricultural machinery.

The European Union (EU) said the withdrawal of all Russian forces from Ukraine would be one of the main conditions to lift or amend EU sanctions on Russia.

If sanctions on Russian oil exports are lifted and the US increases oil production as promised, oil prices in the international market could return to pre-war levels. This would greatly benefit Bangladesh.

The deal will have a ripple effect on Bangladesh's economy — government subsidies on electricity and fuel will decrease, transportation costs in the private sector will fall, and it will strengthen Bangladesh's forex reserves while stabilising the exchange rate.

The Russia-Ukraine war disrupted Bangladesh's imports, particularly wheat and fertilisers, which led to high prices.

US sanctions on Russian banks further complicated transactions for the $12 billion Rooppur Nuclear Power Plant, 90% of which is financed by Russia. Bangladesh now owes Russia over $1 billion in interest and fees, delaying the project. Recent payment attempts through Sonali Bank were blocked by Standard Chartered Bank in New York.

The Rooppur loan transaction complications would be resolved if the US withdrew sanctions on Russian institutions. If the SWIFT transaction ban on Russia is lifted, payments for Rooppur can begin. If the US lifts sanctions on Rosatom, transactions can proceed smoothly. Rosatom, Russia's State Atomic Energy Corporation, is implementing the Rooppur power project.

Bangladesh's garment exports were also significantly impacted due to the war. Apparel makers have said nearly 4% of Bangladesh's garment export market is in Russia. Due to the Black Sea crisis, goods were rerouted through other countries to reach Russia, raising costs and reducing export volumes.

If the Black Sea issue is resolved, the struggling export market in Russia will revive, and garment exports will increase.

If the US lifts sanctions on Russia, Bangladesh's RMG sector will benefit significantly. In recent years, new markets for garment exports were emerging in Russia, but the war has put those prospects at risk.

Bangladesh imports a large quantity of food products from Russia and Ukraine. Importing from alternative countries has significantly increased prices, creating a food crisis. If the Black Sea becomes safe again, the additional costs will decrease, and imports and exports will return to normal.

Before the Ukraine-Russia war, the price of crude oil was below $50 per barrel. During the war, it rose to $130, and now it is around $70-72. If sanctions on Russian oil exports are lifted and the US increases oil production as promised, oil prices in the international market could return to pre-war levels.

If oil prices fall in the international market, LNG and coal prices will follow suit. Both the government and private sector in Bangladesh will significantly benefit. This will lead to lower energy and transportation costs for the private sector.

The Black Sea deal will have a significant impact on the global energy market and Bangladesh will benefit as well, since the country is fully dependent on imports for both refined and unrefined petroleum products.

The article was written by Shaikh Abdullah & Abul Kashem.

title: Trump tariffs impact markets and economy. Should Congress intervene? | Opinion - (Published 22 hour(s), 26 minute(s) ago)
content: Under the U.S. Constitution, Congress directly holds the power to impose and collect tariffs. What's stopping Congress from intervening now?
resumen: Under the U.S. Constitution, Congress directly holds the power to impose and collect tariffs. Article I, Section 8 grants Congress the authority "to lay and collect Taxes, Duties, Imposts and Excises" and "to regulate Commerce with foreign Nations." Much of the authority of the President in this area is a result of the Congress delegating its own authority through the passage of laws. The current law provides specific conditions under which the President can modify tariffs but usually require some form of justification. The Reciprocal Tariff Act of 1934 allowed the President to negotiate tariff reductions. In 1962, Congress gave the President the ability to adjust tariffs if imports were deemed a threat to national security. The Trade Act of 1974 permits tariff adjustments in response to unfair trade practices by foreign governments. In times of national emergencies, the International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977 gives the President broad authority to restrict trade. Executive actions can and are regularly challenged in the U.S. courts. Judges generally uphold presidential actions if they stay within the boundaries set by Congress. In United States v. Yoshida International, Inc. (1975), a court examined whether an import surcharge proclaimed by the President was legally permissible under federal law. The court noted, “In a statute dealing with foreign affairs, a grant to the President which is expansive to the reader's eye should not be hemmed in or 'cabined, cribbed, confined' by anxious judicial blinders.” Kevin Wagner is a noted constitutional scholar and political science professor at Florida Atlantic University.

title: Japan 'deeply concerned' about global economic fallout from Trump's trade tariffs: Kato - (Published 9 hour(s), 46 minute(s) ago)
content: Japan is "deeply concerned" about global economic fallout from U.S. President Donald Trump's trade tariffs, Finance Minister Katsunobu Kato said on Thursday in the government's strongest warning yet ...
resumen: Japan is "deeply concerned" about global economic fallout from U.S. President Donald Trump's trade tariffs, according to Finance Minister Katsunobu Kato. Kato voiced concern over recent volatile market moves triggered by Trump's tariff announcements, saying they could hurt Japan's economic recovery. Kato said the U.S. tariff measures affect various industries and heighten uncertainty and could affect Japan's economy, as well as the global economy, through various routes such as trade and financial markets. Kato plans to go to Washington next week for meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the Group of 20. Kato is also expected to meet separately with Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent. Kato said there's a risk of exerting downward pressure on Japan's economy from the U.S. tariffs and the ensuing market volatility. Kato said he will "closely communicate" with the U.S. on currency issues, adding Tokyo and Washington have long agreed that excessive volatility and disorderly moves in currency rates are undesirable. Kato declined to comment on how any discussions on currencies could unfold once he meets Bessent. Trump has indicated he wants the trade talks to include his accusations that Japan intentionally weakens the yen to help its exporters and his complaints that Japan does not pay enough to support U.S. troops based in the country. Japan, which denies manipulating its currency, wants to avoid such topics. Trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa said exchange rates did not come up in Wednesday's talks. Akazawa also brushed aside the idea that Washington might seek a coordinated effort to weaken the dollar. The policy chief of Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba's ruling party, Itsunori Onodera, said on Sunday that Japan must strengthen the yen, such as by helping boost the country's industrial competitiveness, to fight inflation. Kato stressed that monetary policy decisions fall under the jurisdiction of the Bank of Japan but said the government will deepen dialogue with the central bank on the economy, including the impact of U.S. tariffs. Kato said there is no change to their expectations the BOJ would guide monetary policy appropriately to achieve its 2% inflation target in a stable and durable manner. In the bilateral trade negotiations, Japan should explain how it can help the U.S. resuscitate its ailing manufacturing sector and narrow the huge U.S. trade deficit, Kato said.

title: Tariffs could cost the average American household $3,800 per year. Here’s how to save for it - (Published 15 hour(s), 3 minute(s) ago)
content: Tariffs could cost households $3,800 in 2025. Discover smart budgeting strategies to offset rising prices on consumer goods.
resumen:
Tariffs could cost the average American household $3,800 in 2025, according to The Budget Lab at Yale University. President Trump announced a 90-day pause on tariffs earlier this month, temporarily reducing most tariffs to 10% while maintaining higher rates for countries including China. Tariffs — taxes imposed on imported goods — typically cause prices to rise as companies pass these additional costs to consumers.

Key takeaways:

*   Tariffs will raise consumer prices on goods, including cars, electronics, clothing and furniture, potentially costing the average household up to $3,800 in 2025.
*   Savings account yields may stay elevated as the Federal Reserve holds rates steady in response to inflation risks.
*   Cut nonessential spending and boost your emergency fund if you can, which can help offset the financial impact of rising prices in the future.
*   Maximize your savings by storing your money in high-yield savings accounts and CDs.

Products expected to be impacted by tariffs, according to Yale’s Budget Lab study, include:

*   Electronics: Smartphones, laptops and televisions could see prices increases of up to 4.5 percent.
*   Clothing and apparel: Leather products and apparel are the two categories expected to see the highest price hikes. The Budget Lab estimates that these products will go up by 18.3 and 16.9 percent, respectively.
*   Automobiles: Both new and used vehicles may become more expensive, with an estimated 8.4 percent increase for motor vehicles and parts.
*   Furniture and household goods: Imported furniture, including tables, chairs and home decor. Textiles (9.6 percent), wood products (3.3 percent) and rubber and plastic (6.4 percent) products are all expected to increase in price.
*   Raw materials: Products made from materials like steel, aluminum and other metals may see prices increases of around 5.8 percent.

The Fed began lowering interest rates in September 2024 as inflation approached its 2 percent target. In March 2025, citing economic uncertainty, the Fed paused its rate-cutting cycle and kept rates unchanged. The March CPI report shows a notable cooling in inflation.

4 budgeting strategies to offset tariff costs:

1.  Track spending and cut back where you can.
2.  Increase your emergency fund. Experts generally recommend saving three to six months’ worth of essential expenses.
3.  Time your major purchases strategically.
4.  Compare prices across retailers and countries of origin.

Many of the largest institutions, such as Bank of America and Chase Bank, offer savings accounts with rock-bottom rates of 0.01 to 0.02 percent APY. Top-notch accounts currently offer yields above four percent APY. CDs are also a great option to stash extra savings.

content: California impugnará ante los tribunales los aranceles impuestos por el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, anunció este miércoles su ...
resumen:
California demandará a Donald Trump por los aranceles e intentará revertir las medidas.
California es la quinta economía más grande del mundo y alberga la mayor parte de producción manufacturera de Estados Unidos.
El gobernador Newson afirmó que California podría perder miles de millones de dólares en ingresos si las políticas arancelarias de Trump contraen el comercio internacional.
California impugnará ante los tribunales los aranceles impuestos por Donald Trump, anunció el gobernador demócrata Gavin Newsom.
La oficina de Newsom afirmó que California podría perder miles de millones de dólares en ingresos si las políticas arancelarias de Trump contraen el comercio internacional.
Solo cuatro países tienen un PIB mayor que el de California.
El gobernador denunció "la autoridad unilateral reclamada por la administración Trump para imponer la mayor subida de gravámenes de la historia moderna de Estados Unidos".
California argumenta que la ley en la que se apoya Trump para imponer estos aranceles no le habilita a gravar las importaciones estadounidenses de forma unilateral.
"California es el mayor estado manufacturero de nuestra unión, uno de los mayores socios comerciales del mundo. Ningún estado se verá más afectado que el estado de California", insistió Newsom, de quien se espera que se presente como candidato a la presidencia en 2028.
A principios de abril, el gobernador ya anunció que California saldrá a negociar acuerdos comerciales con países de todo el mundo para no verse afectada por las posibles represalias contra los productos estadounidenses.
El fiscal general de California, Rob Bonta, dijo: "Estamos pidiendo al tribunal que frene al presidente (...) y defienda la Constitución".
El caso es el último de más de una decena de demandas que California ha presentado contra la administración Trump.
Siendo el estado más poblado del país, con 39 millones de habitantes, California representa el 14% del PIB estadounidense.
Su economía depende estrechamente de la relación con México, Canadá y China, todos objetivos de Trump desde su vuelta a la Casa Blanca a finales de enero.

title: China Wants Countries to Unite Against Trump, but Is Met With Wariness - (Published Apr 16, 2025)
content: Beijing is using a mix of carrots and sticks to try to prevent other countries from siding with the United States in isolating China.
resumen: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, and his subordinates are mounting a diplomatic full court press to try to persuade other countries not to cave to pressure from the Trump administration on tariffs. China hopes to show that it will not be isolated in the trade war. China’s commerce minister has held a video call with the European Union’s top trade official, pushing for closer cooperation. Chinese diplomats have been contacting officials in Tokyo and Seoul. Mr. Xi landed in Vietnam and Malaysia on state visits this week. At stake for Mr. Xi is the fate of the global trading system that propelled China’s rise as the world’s manufacturing powerhouse, as well as access to markets for many Chinese exports now that the United States has sought to cut them off with debilitating tariffs. The outreach is also a test of China’s status as a global power in the face of what Beijing sees as an effort by Washington to contain and suppress its key rival. China has fought back against the Trump administration with its own eye-watering tariffs on U.S. goods, as well as restrictions on the export of some rare earth minerals and magnets that are vital for assembling cars, missiles and drones. Mr. Xi has tried to assemble a broader coalition to his side — hoping to keep countries from slapping tariffs of their own on Chinese products, or giving in to Washington’s demands to decouple from Chinese manufacturing. During his travels in Southeast Asia this week, he has depicted China as a leading defender of the global order and indirectly cast the United States as an unreliable player. In Hanoi, he urged Vietnam to join China in opposing “unilateral bullying.” In Kuala Lumpur, he urged Southeast Asian nations to also “reject decoupling, supply disruption,” and “tariff abuse.” Chinese officials have quietly conveyed that the way the U.S. treats its longstanding allies and partners in Europe is a sign of what’s to come for Southeast Asia. With Trump’s steep, sweeping tariffs across the region, that message needs no reinforcement. Mr. Xi’s attempts at presenting China as a paragon of free trade and a champion of the rules-based international order ignores years of Beijing’s own coercive economic behavior and generous subsidies for select industries that have often alienated the country’s trading partners and neighbors. The European Union, Japan and South Korea have pushed back at attempts by China to suggest that they had agreed with China to jointly fight back against Mr. Trump’s tariffs. Last week, Australia rejected a call by China’s ambassador, Xiao Qian, to “join hands” in rebuffing the Trump administration. Beijing is not filling the vacuum of trust left by the U.S., just offering immediate relief from the shock therapy the Trump administration has forced upon the world. Mr. Xi’s long-planned trip to Vietnam this week, followed by a visit to Malaysia before a stop in Cambodia, has taken on more urgency for China now that President Trump is using his 90-day pause on his “Liberation Day” tariff hikes to press countries to negotiate trade deals with the United States. Beijing’s fear, analysts say, is that these deals will isolate China by including agreements that choke off Chinese exports. Vietnam lavished Mr. Xi with the rare honor of being greeted by a Vietnamese president on the airport tarmac when he arrived in the country on Monday. Hanoi resisted agreeing with Mr. Xi’s boldest comments condemning protectionism, and ultimately signed onto a vague joint statement opposing “hegemonism and power politics” — an accusation that many in Vietnam assign to China during territorial disputes in the South China Sea. For Vietnam, the threat of a 46 percent U.S. levy prompted teams of negotiators to head to Washington to make an appeal for lower tariffs. The Vietnamese government this week promised to crack down on trade fraud — widely seen as a reference to companies shipping Chinese products through Vietnam to evade U.S. tariffs. Mr. Trump kept the pressure on Hanoi, telling reporters on Monday that Mr. Xi’s meeting with Vietnam’s top leader, To Lam, was probably focused on how to “screw” America. Hanoi is being careful not to signal a tilt too far toward Beijing, especially in areas that could displease the Trump administration. Ultimately, Hanoi is still hedging between the world’s two great powers. Vietnam risks retaliation from its much bigger neighbor if Beijing determines that Hanoi is trying to curry favor with the Trump administration at China’s expense. China placed tariffs of up to 100 percent on canola, pork and other foods from Canada last month in a clear warning to countries not to cooperate with Washington on trade. If trading partners “pander to the United States, they will hurt China and at the same time, they will hurt their own country as well.” That threat was reinforced on Sunday by Yuyuan Tantian, a blog affiliated with China’s state broadcaster, CCTV. China would not comment on talks between other countries and the United States. If anyone uses China’s interests as a token of allegiance to the United States, China will never agree! Mr. Xi’s expression of “deep friendship” with Vietnam during his visit came not long after China held live-fire drills in the Gulf of Tonkin to reassert its territorial claims in those waters over Hanoi. Xi doesn’t necessarily need these countries to choose Beijing. He just needs to prevent them from choosing Washington.

title: Singapore to expand trade pacts, push WTO reform amid escalating US-China tensions: DPM Gan - (Published Apr 16, 2025)
content: SINGAPORE] Singapore will expand trade ties, forge new alliances and push to reform the World Trade Organization (WTO) in response to escalating global trade tensions, said Deputy Prime Minister Gan ...
resumen:
Singapore will expand trade ties, forge new alliances and push to reform the World Trade Organization (WTO) in response to escalating global trade tensions, said Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong at an event on Thursday (Apr 17).

DPM Gan said the US President Donald Trump’s “reciprocal tariffs” has upended the cornerstone of the rules-based trading order – something especially vital to Singapore – and warned that the tariffs and reshoring efforts could undermine the Republic’s ability to attract investments and create good jobs.

The US is the largest investor in both Singapore and Asean, and a pullback in trade and investment would weigh on regional growth.

The new Singapore Economic Resilience Taskforce, which DPM Gan is chairing, includes five Cabinet ministers and was formed in response to the US tariffs. It will focus on three areas: “sense-making” and communication, immediate support measures, and longer-term strategies.

Singapore will work with “like-minded countries” across three key focus areas:

1.  Expand its trade partnerships. Singapore already has a “comprehensive network” of 27 free-trade agreements (FTAs) in force. The Pacific Alliance-Singapore FTA with Chile and Peru will come into effect in May, and the government is working towards bringing the Mercosur-Singapore FTA into force. These FTAs are expected to strengthen economic ties between Singapore and eight Latin American countries, including Argentina, Brazil and Mexico.
2.  Forge new alliances. Efforts include working with Asean countries to explore opportunities with the Gulf Cooperation Council, which comprises Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Bahrain and Oman. Singapore is also looking to partner members of the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership to build new links with the European Union.
3.  Reform the WTO and strengthen the multilateral trading system. Singapore wants to work with countries, including the US, to achieve this reform. Singapore has been working with Australia, Japan and about 70 other nations to establish the Joint Statement Initiative on E-Commerce.

The brinkmanship between the US and China will impact not just the global economy, but also regional peace and stability. Tit-for-tat tariffs – with Chinese goods facing a 145 per cent tariff and US goods a 125 per cent tariff – threaten to choke off more than US$600 billion in annual trade.

title: Los aranceles de Trump abren oportunidades en Latinoamérica a UE o India, según expertos - (Published Apr 16, 2025)
content: Madrid, 17 abr (EFE).- La agresiva política arancelaria de Donald Trump va dirigida principalmente a China, por ello los países latinoamericanos, cuyos principales socios comerciales son las dos ...
resumen:
La agresiva política arancelaria de Donald Trump va dirigida principalmente a China, por ello los países latinoamericanos buscan reducir su dependencia de ambas potencias y diversificar, abriendo oportunidades a potencias intermedias.

La Unión Europea e India son dos de las mejor posicionadas, según Javier Fernández Aparicio, autor de un documento de análisis que sobre este tema publica el Instituto Español de Estudios Estratégicos (IEEE).

China ha logrado superar a Estados Unidos como principal socio comercial en Brasil, Chile y Perú.

China tiene acuerdos de libre comercio con Chile (país que cuenta con el 34% de las reservas mundiales de litio), Costa Rica, Ecuador, Nicaragua y Perú, y ha fortalecido los lazos económicos a través de asociaciones estratégicas integrales con Argentina, Brasil, México, Perú y Venezuela.

22 países de América Latina y el Caribe han firmado acuerdos con China en el marco de las iniciativas de la Franja y la Ruta.

Biden ya empezó a hablar de la necesidad de recuperar influencia en Latinoamérica, pero nunca con el tono de Trump, que quiere imponerse con medidas agresivas como los aranceles, que graban especialmente a China y a los países que actúan como intermediarios de la producción china o tienen una relación comercial estrecha con el gigante asiático.

La amenaza de Trump de apoderarse del canal de Panamá "ha sido muy mal recibida en Latinoamérica".

La mejor alternativa es buscar nuevos socios para desacoplarse de China sin incrementar los negocios de Estados Unidos.

Esta opción abre una ventana de oportunidad a las potencias medias o regionales con interés en la región como UE o India.

La Unión Europea puede aprovechar la coyuntura para revertir la situación.

El análisis del IEEE destaca a la India como bien posicionado porque comparte con Brasil varios foros internacionales, en especial los BRICS y el G20.

India tiene una rivalidad geopolítica con China que agrada a Estados Unidos y, a su vez, también a las potencias regionales de latinoamericanas.

La debilidad de Latinoamérica reside en la falta de una política suprarregional.

Fernández Aparicio pone como ejemplo el gran puerto Chancay en Perú -cuyo mayor accionista es una empresa china-, que Chile ve como una amenaza para las operaciones de sus puertos.

title: Trump-China trade war: Which US companies could be worst hit? - (Published Apr 16, 2025)
content: Beijing has also responded to Trump’s moves with retaliatory tariffs of its own, now at 125 percent. US exports to China, and agricultural products in particular, will be hit badly by China’s blanket ...
resumen:
From Apple to Nvidia, United States tech companies have received a temporary exemption from President Donald Trump’s sky-high tariffs. Trump doubled down on China, eventually increasing import taxes on its goods to 145 percent. Beijing has also responded to Trump’s moves with retaliatory tariffs of its own, now at 125 percent. The total goods trade between the US and China stood at $582.4bn in 2024. US imports from China totalled $438.9bn while its exports the other way tallied in at $143.5bn. The US trade deficit with China was $295.4bn last year. China’s Ministry of Commerce said it was increasing tariffs on US goods from 84 percent to 125 percent. The Trump administration announced temporary exemptions for smartphones, solar panels and other electronic products like semiconductor chips from Trump’s “reciprocal” tariffs. As of now, they are still subject to the 20 percent tariffs that Trump imposed on all Chinese goods before April 2. Tariffs could cause 740,000 people to lose their jobs across the US by the end of 2025.

The price of Nike trainers, Levi jeans and Gap T-shirts will almost certainly rise in the US as tariffs undermine the Asian factory hubs that underpin the global clothing industry. In 2024, factories in China, Vietnam and Indonesia made 95 percent of all Nike footwear. Trump has already introduced 145 percent tariffs on China while Vietnam and Indonesia currently face 10 percent tariffs, which could go up in July if they don’t succeed in striking a trade deal with Washington by then. Gap shares have fallen by 14 percent. For Nike, it’s 14.7 percent. Levi’s stock price has plunged by 10.6 percent.

US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) issued a notice exempting some technology products from the tariffs placed on Chinese goods. The CBP listed 20 product categories, including computers, smartphones and automatic data processors. It also included semiconductor equipment, memory chips and flat panel displays. These electronic goods still face 20 percent tariffs that Trump had imposed on them before April 2. Trump has also said the exemptions are temporary, and new tariffs might be coming soon. On Monday he announced an investigation into the national security implications of importing semiconductors and chip-making equipment. Apple outsources most of its assembly operations to China. Almost 90 percent of gaming consoles sold in the US by Sony, Microsoft and Nintendo have been shipped in from China. Nvidia relies heavily on components from China.

Trump’s first trade war with China from 2018 to 2019 resulted in billions of dollars of lost revenue for American farmers. About 15 percent of US farm exports went to China in 2024. The soya bean sector, in particular, stands to lose because China is its largest export market. When Trump imposed tariffs on Chinese goods in his first presidential term, Beijing retaliated by buying soya beans from other countries like Brazil. It also imposed retaliatory tariffs of its own. This time around, those tariffs are five times higher. The American Soybean Association has publicly opposed Trump’s tariffs on China. The US has more than 500,000 soya bean producers, according to the Department of Agriculture’s Census of Agriculture. That includes at least 223,000 full-time jobs supported by the soya bean industry, according to a 2023 report for the National Oilseed Processors Association and the United Soybean Board. The industry is worth $124bn in the US. Corn and pig farmers have also been urging the Trump administration to step back from its tariff spat. Cargill, Archer Daniels Midland and Tyson Foods are three of several large US food companies that will likely lose export earnings from China.

content: Farmers across the country continue to largely support the US president. However, they hope to avoid the fallout of the Trump administration's tariffs dispute and secure assistance from the federal ...

US farmers are deeply concerned by the impact of Trump's trade war.

John Fleming, a fifth-generation farmer born in Halifax County in the heart of North Carolina, anxiously watched the numbers on his computer screen: The prices of cotton, soybeans and corn were plummeting. On Monday, April 7, the markets plunged again, five days after Donald Trump's "Liberation Day" with the announcement of massive tariffs. The 44-year-old farmer, with his red beard and coffee thermos in hand, will not plant cotton this year: The price of $0.649 per pound is below the break-even point. He now awaits the repercussions of the new tariffs: "I hope that it's gonna be a short-term pain, for a long-term gain." The wish has been echoed by MAGA (Make America Great Again) Republican lawmakers and ultraconservative Fox News editorialists in recent days: "It will be worth the pain.". John Fleming, a fifth-generation farmer who grows soybeans, corn and other crops, some of which are intended for export, on his farm in Halifax, North Carolina, April 7, 2025. In North Carolina, a swing state that Trump won by 185,000 votes in November 2024 and the fifth-largest US exporter to China, anxiety mingled with hope among farmers. Nearly 80% of agricultural counties in the United States voted for Trump, according to the US Department of Agriculture. Fleming hesitated to reveal that he voted for the MAGA champion, fearing activists might set his tractor on fire just as they damage Tesla cars, the company owned by Trump adviser Elon Musk.

title: Trump Has Botched His Tariff War With China - (Published Apr 16, 2025)
content: Mr. Trump seems to have forgotten these things. His ill-conceived and amateurishly executed tariff war with China has now spiraled out of control, threatening world trade and badly damaging America’s ...
resumen:
President Trump’s trade war with China began last week and has already faltered. Trump and his team wrongly assumed China would yield to protect its exports to the United States. China exports $438 billion to the United States in 2024. The tariffs imposed by Trump and matched by Beijing will hurt China, especially with weak consumer demand and a struggling real estate market. China is better prepared to hold its ground than during Trump’s first term.

China is less economically tied to the United States than before. In 2017, 21.6 percent of goods imported into the United States came from China, falling to 13.4 percent last year. China has diversified its export markets, with direct exports to the United States being roughly the same as a decade ago, while exports to the European Union soared. Exports as a percentage of China’s gross domestic product declined from 36 percent in 2006 to 19.7 percent in 2023, according to World Bank data.

China, under President Xi Jinping, has prepared for this trade confrontation by prioritizing technological self-sufficiency, economic security, and industrial retooling. China has taken steps to strengthen the economy and promote domestic consumption.

Trump declared a 90-day pause in tariffs after they sparked fears of a recession and crashed global financial markets. His admission that he backed off because investors were getting “yippy” was unwise.

The Chinese government can use policy tools to ease the pain of a prolonged trade war, including billions of dollars in state funds. Trump’s negotiating position will weaken as U.S. consumers feel rising inflation and investors suffer.

China’s leaders are not as vulnerable to domestic pressure as Trump. Recurring periods of hardship in Chinese history have embedded a capacity for endurance and fortitude, known as “chi ku.”

Both China and the United States are trying to change their economic models. China wants to shift toward more consumption, and the United States wants to produce more.

Trump says Beijing “played it wrong” by retaliating against his tariffs. A downturn in global demand caused by his tariffs would affect the Chinese economy.

Trump’s approach has raised the risk of a world recession and made China appear like the more stable and reliable economic partner.

content: Trump's "America First" trade policy could bring global economy to its knees, with China retaliating against reciprocal tariffs.
resumen: Following the launch of Donald Trump’s “America First” trade policy, China retaliated. China announced its decision to impose retaliatory tariffs equivalent to the 34% “reciprocal tariff” it faced. Mr. Trump imposed an additional tariff of 50%, raising the overall tariff burden to 104%. China then imposed 125% tariffs on all its imports from the U.S., which led to the White House increasing tariffs again to 145%. Washington tacitly admitted to the potential impact these tariffs would bring by exempting a number of critical electronic goods, including computers, laptops, smartphones, and semiconductor devices, from such tariffs. Commerce Secretary, Howard Lutnick, informed that tariffs on electronics products would be included within semiconductor tariffs in a “month or two”, only to be contradicted by the President, who declared that these tariffs would be imposed sooner. In 2018, the U.S. was China’s largest export market with a 19.2% share. Over the past six years, China reduced this figure to below 15% and in the first quarter of 2025, only 13.5% of China’s exports reached the U.S. China has diversified its export markets, with ASEAN emerging as the most significant destination. China’s control over the rare earth market accounts for 92% of global output. China has already shown its hand by imposing export restrictions on seven types of rare earth minerals in the past few days. China is the second largest holder of U.S. Treasury bonds, but in recent years, it has been gradually selling its holdings. Since 2018, China has reduced its holdings from $1.2 trillion (22% of the total) to $761 billion (less than 9%) in January 2025.

title: Recomendaciones para los inversionistas guatemaltecos en medio de los aranceles de Trump - (Published Apr 16, 2025)
content: Los empresarios guatemaltecos pueden adoptar estrategias específicas para enfrentar los desafíos derivados de los aranceles y la volatilidad en los mercados internacionales. Conozca la ...
resumen:
Los empresarios guatemaltecos pueden adoptar estrategias específicas para enfrentar los desafíos derivados de los aranceles y la volatilidad en los mercados internacionales.

Iván Higueros, Ceo de Zona Trading, comentó que los aranceles proteccionistas impuestos por la administración de Donald Trump han generado inestabilidad en los mercados internacionales y afectado directamente a exportadores guatemaltecos.

Para los empresarios guatemaltecos, es clave integrar el análisis bursátil en su estrategia para anticiparse a riesgos y aprovechar oportunidades en este panorama económico cambiante, recomendó Higueros.

Los aranceles impuestos por la administración de Donald Trump han generado una fuerte inestabilidad en los mercados internacionales. Estas medidas proteccionistas han tenido un impacto directo en el comercio global, provocando caídas significativas y correcciones históricas en las bolsas de valores.

En el caso específico de Guatemala, el impacto no ha sido únicamente indirecto. También hemos sufrido consecuencias directas con la imposición de los llamados "aranceles universales" del 10% sobre todas las importaciones hacia Estados Unidos, y tarifas incluso más altas para 57 socios comerciales clave. Esta medida afecta considerablemente a los exportadores guatemaltecos, quienes hoy enfrentan una presión sin precedentes.

Comprender el comportamiento de las bolsas de valores es clave para cualquier inversionista o analista serio. Las bolsas funcionan como un verdadero termómetro del estado general de la economía: nos muestran cómo están las expectativas del mercado en relación con el futuro de las empresas, el entorno macroeconómico y la estabilidad política global.

Ante estos movimientos, hay tres caminos posibles para quienes participan en el mercado: comprar, vender o mantener sus posiciones. Cada una de estas decisiones está relacionada con el perfil del inversionista, su estrategia y su percepción del riesgo.

Cuando hablamos de que las bolsas “cierran en rojo”, nos referimos a que los principales índices bursátiles de esa jornada terminaron con una caída respecto al cierre del día anterior.

Por el contrario, si decimos que una bolsa "cerró en verde", significa que los índices subieron con relación al cierre anterior.

También existen días en que el mercado cierra "en mixto". Esto sucede cuando no hay una tendencia clara entre los principales índices: algunos cierran al alza y otros a la baja.

La sostenibilidad del comportamiento actual de las bolsas de valores depende de múltiples factores interconectados en los ámbitos macroeconómico, político y social. Los mercados financieros reaccionan de forma directa a elementos como las políticas gubernamentales, las tasas de interés, la inflación y, más recientemente, a tensiones comerciales como las que provocaron los aranceles impuestos durante la administración Trump.

Para los empresarios medianos y grandes en Guatemala, comprender la lectura de los mercados bursátiles internacionales no es una opción, sino una necesidad estratégica. Aunque en muchos casos no participen directamente en la bolsa, las decisiones que se toman en estos mercados afectan de forma indirecta, pero significativa, sus operaciones, costos de importación, acceso a financiamiento, e incluso la demanda internacional de sus productos.

La recomendación es que incorporen el análisis del comportamiento bursátil como parte de su planificación financiera y toma de decisiones. La bolsa es un reflejo de lo que está ocurriendo a nivel macroeconómico y político en el mundo.

content: En marzo, las remesas a República Dominicana alcanzaron 1,110.3 millones de dólares, un crecimiento del 20 % respecto al año anterior.
resumen: En marzo, República Dominicana recibió 1,110.3 millones de dólares en remesas, un 20 % más que en el mismo mes del año anterior y un 21.2 % más que en febrero de 2025. El 83.9 % de las remesas formales de marzo, 867 millones de dólares, provinieron de Estados Unidos. España fue el segundo país de origen, con 65.5 millones de dólares, el 6.3 % del total. Italia aportó el 1.1 %, Haití el 1.0 %, y Suiza el 1.0 %. Las reservas internacionales del país superan los 14,700 millones de dólares, el 11.7 % del producto interno bruto (PIB), cubriendo 5.3 meses de importaciones. El Banco Central proyecta para 2025: ingresos por turismo de 11,400 millones de dólares, remesas por encima de 10,900 millones de dólares, exportaciones totales de 14,800 millones de dólares, e inversión extranjera directa (IED) superior a 4,700 millones de dólares. Los ingresos totales por divisas superarían los 45,600 millones de dólares al cierre del año.

title: Chile presentó el plan de obras del Corredor Bioceánico Vial con Brasil, Argentina y Paraguay - (Published 13 hour(s), 26 minute(s) ago)
content: Chile presentó el lunes el plan de obras de infraestructura del llamado Corredor Bioceánico Vial, una carretera que busca unir el norte del país con Argentina, Paraguay y Brasil para configurar una ...
resumen: Chile presentó el plan de obras del Corredor Bioceánico Vial con Brasil, Argentina y Paraguay. El proyecto es considerado una de las obras de infraestructura más importantes de América Latina, con una extensión de 2.400 km. Chile presentó el lunes el plan de obras de infraestructura del llamado Corredor Bioceánico Vial, una carretera que busca unir el norte del país con Argentina, Paraguay y Brasil para configurar una nueva ruta comercial entre el Atlántico y el Asia-Pacífico. El proyecto está en carpeta desde hace una década y es considerado una de las obras de infraestructura más importantes de América Latina, con una extensión de 2.400 km. El trazado conecta los puertos del sur de Brasil con los del norte de Chile, atravesando Mato Grosso do Sul, el chaco paraguayo, las provincias argentinas de Salta y Jujuy, según la descripción del proyecto. El presidente Gabriel Boric, al presentar el “Plan de acción del corredor bioceánico” el lunes en el palacio presidencial de La Moneda, dijo: “Es una buena noticia, porque se trata de una integración real y concreta”. El plan considera el desarrollo de 22 proyectos de infraestructura en Chile para mejorar carreteras, establecer nuevos puntos de control de la aduana y la policía, además de la actualización de los puertos de Iquique, Mejillones y Antofagasta en el norte del país. No se detalló el monto de inversión de las obras comprometidas. De acuerdo con el gobierno chileno, este corredor representa una mejora significativa frente a otras rutas. Se espera que pueda reducir hasta 10 días el transporte entre regiones mediterráneas de Brasil y Paraguay y países del Asia-Pacífico como China, Corea del Sur o Japón. El programa será uno de los puntos centrales de discusión de la visita oficial que Boric realizará la próxima semana a Brasil.

Un 82% de los mexicanos aprueba su gestión, de acuerdo con una encuesta realizada por Enkoll para EL PAÍS y W Radio en marzo de 2025. La mayoría de los encuestados, un 67%, considera que la situación del país ha mejorado desde la llegada de Sheinbaum al poder. La lista Time 100 se publica desde 1999. Este año, Donald Trump fue incluido por séptima ocasión, mientras que Elon Musk aparece por sexta ocasión en la lista. Otras figuras que forman parte del conteo son la tenista Serena Williams, el rapero Snoop Dogg, el CEO de Meta, Mark Zuckerberg, el vicepresidente de Estados Unidos J. D. Vance y la actriz Demi Moore.

title: How China’s Companies Are Responding to the US Trade War - (Published 16 hour(s), 12 minute(s) ago)
content: Chinese firms have been pursuing internal reforms, supply chain restructurings, and accelerated innovation, with the result of “selective decoupling” from the U.S.
resumen:
Since 2018, Chinese firms have been pursuing internal reforms, supply chain restructurings, and accelerated innovation, resulting in “selective decoupling” from the U.S. The trade conflict between China and the United States has served as a catalyst for internal transformation within Chinese enterprises. Under the pressure of U.S. tariffs since 2018, Chinese firms have been forced to choose between adaptation and obsolescence, triggering internal reforms, supply chain restructurings, and accelerated technological innovation. The trade war has induced significant structural changes at the firm level in China, advancing corporate resilience and reform. Chinese enterprises have proactively responded through strategic overseas investments, reassessment of supply chains, and expedited technological upgrading. These transformations suggest that the process of China-U.S. “economic decoupling” is unfolding largely through firm-level strategic decisions and adaptive behavior.

The trade war has increased the costs associated with exporting goods directly from China to the United States, compelling Chinese enterprises to reevaluate their industrial chains and trade routes, triggering supply chain restructuring and market diversification. Many Chinese companies sought to circumvent U.S. tariff barriers by relocating production to third countries. Labor-intensive sectors have seen the most pronounced trends toward relocation, while capital-intensive sectors have been far more reluctant to relocate. Much of the capacity leaving China has been redirected to emerging economies in Asia.

Chinese enterprises have actively explored new export markets to reduce their dependence on the United States. Companies have increased their marketing efforts in Europe, Southeast Asia, Africa, and Latin America. The relative importance of the United States in China’s export structure has declined yearly, while South–South trade between China and developing countries has been steadily expanding. By 2023–2024, about 30 percent of Chinese exports were destined for G-7 developed economies – down from nearly 48 percent in 2000. Exports to emerging markets and countries along the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) have surged. Chinese enterprises have also sought new import channels to reduce dependence on the United States for critical goods and technologies. Following the imposition of retaliatory tariffs on U.S. agricultural products, Chinese importers pivoted toward suppliers in Brazil and Argentina. In high-tech component imports, Chinese firms have actively pursued non-U.S. supply chains. Huawei has incorporated a greater number of domestically produced components and memory chips in its latest flagship smartphone, the Pura 70. This adjustment has enhanced firms’ resilience to external shocks and has broader geopolitical implications, fostering a trend of economic “decoupling.” However, Chinese enterprises face obstacles in new markets, including differences in regulatory standards, intellectual property disputes, and resistance from local governments or civil society groups.

The most far-reaching transformation catalyzed by the China-U.S. trade war at the enterprise level lies in the acceleration of technological innovation. The United States began to tighten export controls on high-tech products and impose sanctions on Chinese technology companies. Chinese firms faced rising export costs and the heightened risk of being cut off from critical foreign technology. China’s high-tech industrial community rapidly mobilized R&D initiatives aimed at achieving technological self-sufficiency and autonomy. China’s semiconductor industry has accelerated investments in R&D and capacity expansion since 2018. Leading Chinese AI chipmaker Cambricon and CPU design company Loongson have reported that their core business operations are now largely decoupled from the U.S. market and technological ecosystem. In 2024, both companies announced that overseas revenues accounted for less than 1 percent of their total income. Following President Xi Jinping’s call for “sci-tech self-strengthening at higher levels,” Beijing introduced industrial funds and technological support measures. Chinese firms have come to perceive foreign technological chokepoints as existential threats, prompting aggressive efforts toward tech breakthroughs. Chinese firms continue to promote international collaboration. Huawei has continued to partner with local telecom operators in Africa and the Middle East for 5G deployment. In the semiconductor sector, Chinese companies are actively building partnerships with non-sensitive suppliers in Taiwan, South Korea, and Japan. By 2025, China’s pursuit of technological autonomy has begun to yield tangible results. The country’s dependence on imported high-tech products has steadily declined. Since 2020, growth in imports of mechanical, electronic, and high-tech goods has slowed significantly, with some categories even registering negative growth. China’s phased breakthroughs in several critical areas have prompted the United States to reassert trade protectionism and expand technological containment. In 2023, Washington further tightened its export controls on semiconductor manufacturing equipment. The trade war thus injected a new impetus into the long-term “innovation race” between the U.S. and China.

Firm-level transformations within China are collectively reshaping the foundational structure of international economic relations. Empirical evidence suggests that decoupling is unfolding across multiple domains, driven by firms’ strategic adjustments. Trade data reinforces the observation of economic decoupling. As companies reduce their dependence on each other’s markets, the interdependence between the Chinese and U.S. economies is steadily weakening. American retailers are turning to alternative suppliers in countries such as Vietnam, India, and Mexico. China’s procurement from the United States has been declining, while imports from emerging markets and the EU have been rising. At the investment level, Chinese OFDI to the United States has declined sharply since the onset of the trade war. Chinese firms have shown a marked preference for greenfield investments in politically “friendly” or “neutral” countries. In the technology domain, Chinese enterprises continue to advance the development of independent tech ecosystems, potentially leading to the emergence of two distinct technological spheres: one led by China, and the other by the United States. At the supply chain level, structural bifurcation is also becoming increasingly apparent. Numerous multinational corporations are now actively exploring “China-free” or “U.S.-free” supply chains to reduce the risk. Firm-led economic decoupling is likely to generate increasingly complex political consequences. The reduction in economic interdependence threatens to undermine the foundation of China-U.S. relations. The enterprise-level decoupling triggered by the trade war may contribute to the emergence of a more structurally antagonistic international order. Many Western multinationals remain deeply engaged in the Chinese domestic market. Chinese firms continue to rely heavily on select Western technological inputs. The current landscape is thus better described as one of “selective decoupling” or “conditional de-risking.” Even partial fragmentation is likely to exert lasting impacts on global resource allocation and strategic expectations. These transformations are decentralized. Even if China-U.S. tensions were to ease in the future or tariffs were relaxed, the alternative pathways born out of crisis are likely to exhibit “stickiness” and irreversibility.

title: Some decry Trump disruptions. These voters exult in them. - (Published 21 hour(s), 46 minute(s) ago)
content: Just as President Trump’s vision for America has intensified in his second stint in Washington, so, too, has his strongest supporters’ admiration.
resumen: In Keswick, Virginia, a group of neighbors and avid supporters of President Donald Trump, including Michelle de Stefano and Alan Janusziewicz, express their unwavering support for him. They are fine with higher prices and market downturns due to tariffs, believing Trump has earned their complete trust and loyalty. They see him as a disrupter and visionary, not bound by party politics. They support his actions, such as slashing the federal workforce, closing governmental agencies, repealing environmental regulations, stepping up deportation efforts, banning certain programs, and starting a global trade war. They believe he is working for the common man, even if it means crashing the market to wake up the world. They are not concerned about market volatility. They are three-time Trump voters.
