title: Trump’s Trade War with China Intensifies, Threatening Global Economic Stability - (Published 22 hour(s), 11 minute(s) ago)
content: President Donald Trump’s escalating trade war with China has deepened into a high-stakes showdown, with profound implications for the U.S. and global economies. As tariffs soar to unprecedented levels ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump’s escalating trade war with China has deepened into a high-stakes showdown, with profound implications for the U.S. and global economies. Tariffs have soared to unprecedented levels. Both nations dig in, risking a commercial rupture that could slash growth, disrupt supply chains, and spark inflation. The fallout is already rattling markets and raising fears of a recession, while diplomatic tensions threaten to spill beyond trade into broader geopolitical conflict.

On April 14, 2025, the U.S.-China economic clash dominates headlines, with Trump’s administration imposing tariffs as high as 145% on Chinese imports, prompting Beijing to retaliate with 125% duties on American goods. The White House insists the strategy will force China to negotiate, but critics warn the costs—higher prices, job losses, and market volatility—may outweigh any gains.

Trump’s tariff policy, dubbed “Liberation Day” by the president, initially rolled out on April 2, with a 10% tariff on imports from most nations, with steeper levies targeting Canada, Mexico, and China. After global markets plummeted and allies protested, Trump paused hikes on most trading partners for 90 days to allow negotiations. China, however, remains the focal point.

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent has called China “the worst offender in the international trading system,” urging Beijing to address issues like fentanyl exports in exchange for tariff relief. White House trade adviser Peter Navarro emphasized Trump’s “good relationship” with Chinese President Xi Jinping, suggesting an open invitation for talks, though no formal negotiations have materialized.

U.S. consumers face rising prices as the cost of imported goods—from electronics to clothing—climbs. Economists from Goldman Sachs and Oxford Economics predict U.S. growth, which started 2025 at 2.4%, could stall by year’s end. Globally, the conflict may shave 0.4% off economic output, according to Capital Economics. In China, analysts at UBS forecast growth dropping to 4% in 2025, below Beijing’s 5% target, as exports to the U.S. dwindle.

Small businesses, already strained by inflation, are particularly vulnerable. Alan Murphy, CEO of Sea-Intelligence, warned of a “massive restructuring” in shipping as trade flows shift. American retailers, reliant on Chinese goods, scramble to find alternatives. The trade between the U.S. and China, once nearly $700 billion annually, could collapse.

On April 11, Beijing raised duties on U.S. goods to 125%, dismissing Trump’s policies as “economically meaningless.” Xi has rallied European nations to resist what he calls “unilateral bullying,” while boosting ties with Brazil and others to counter U.S. pressure.

China’s shift toward domestic consumption, coupled with export restrictions on rare earths, signals a long-term strategy to weather the storm. Lynn Song, chief economist for Greater China at ING Bank, said, “Beijing isn’t blinking.” Kevin Hassett, director of the National Economic Council, admitted on CNN that discussions with Beijing are “nascent, if at all.”

The S&P 500 dropped 12% in four days before rebounding 10% when Trump paused most tariffs, excluding China. The Nasdaq surged 11% for the week, buoyed by exemptions for tech products like iPhones, but volatility persists.

The U.S. dollar hit a three-year low, and Treasury yields climbed as investors braced for inflation. Consumer sentiment plummeted to its second-lowest level since 1952, with expectations for price growth at a four-decade high.

Boston Fed President Susan Collins warned that sustained tariffs could push inflation above 3% and slow growth. New York Fed President John Williams projected expansion falling below 1%, with inflation between 3.5% and 4%.

Jamie Dimon, CEO of JPMorgan Chase, described the economy as facing “considerable turbulence,” a sentiment echoed by Senate Democrats like Elizabeth Warren, who called the policy a “red light, green light game” of chaos.

A CBS News poll showed a dip in public support, while an Economist/YouGov survey found his job approval sliding after the tariff rollout.

Former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers called the tariffs “the worst self-inflicted wound” since World War II, warning of stagflation.

Trump remains defiant, insisting on Truth Social that his plan is “moving along quickly” and will make the U.S. “bigger and better than ever before.”

China’s outreach to the EU and Latin America aims to counter U.S. influence, while Trump’s pause on tariffs for other nations has spurred talks with over 130 countries, per Hassett. Taiwan held tariff talks with the U.S. on April 12.

Analysts warn that “decoupling”—a near-total severing of U.S.-China economic ties—could destabilize global markets and heighten the risk of conflict.

A brief reprieve for tech giants like Apple, whose iPhones were exempted from the latest tariffs, sparked optimism. Trump signaled on April 13 that chip tariffs could follow.

China’s control of rare earths, vital for electronics and defense, adds another layer of complexity. Xi’s export curbs, announced April 11, sent ripples through global supply chains, highlighting Beijing’s leverage.

Navarro hinted at Trump’s willingness to engage, citing his rapport with Xi. China’s Commerce Ministry called tariff exemptions a “small step,” demanding their complete abolition.

An economist writing in Fortune suggested keeping China’s factories “addicted to cheap exports” via lower tariffs, slowing its tech advances without crippling trade.

Trump’s trade war with China is a gamble of historic proportions.

title: El secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos dijo que no está en consideración otorgar un nuevo crédito a la Argentina - (Published 7 hour(s), 21 minute(s) ago)

title: Trump tariffs: Donald Trump downplays tariffs walk-back, says no country ‘off the hook’ - (Published 7 hour(s), 52 minute(s) ago)
content: Global markets have been on a rollercoaster since Trump’s April 3 tariffs announcement, declining sharply before partially recovering with his 90-day pause on the steepest rates last week. Most ...
resumen:
Donald Trump stated that no country would be getting “off the hook” on tariffs, despite a 90-day reprieve on some levies.

Global markets have been on a rollercoaster since Trump’s April 3 tariffs announcement.

Most nations will now face a baseline 10% tariff for the near-three-month period – except China.

US levies imposed on China have risen to 145% and Beijing set a retaliatory 125% band on US imports.

Trump’s administration has said it intends to negotiate trade deals, including with China.

Trump wrote on his Truth Social platform that “NOBODY is getting ‘off the hook’ for the unfair Trade Balances, and Non-Monetary Tariff Barriers, that other Countries have used against us, especially not China, which, by far, treats us the worst!”.

Trump issued exemptions for Chinese-made semiconductors and electronics.

Trump asserted that there was “no tariff ‘exception’” on those products, saying that they remained subject to a 20% rate in “a different tariff ‘bucket’”.

Beijing’s Commerce Ministry said the weekend’s move only “represents a small step” and insisted that the Trump administration should “completely cancel” the whole tariff strategy.

Some of the exempted consumer electronics are targeted for upcoming sector-specific tariffs.

Xi on Monday kicks off a five-day Southeast Asia tour for talks with the leaders of Vietnam, Malaysia and Cambodia.

The fallout from Trump’s tariffs has sent particular shockwaves through the US economy, with investors dumping government bonds, the dollar tumbling and consumer confidence plunging.

Wall Street billionaires have openly criticised the tariff strategy as damaging and counterproductive.

The White House insists the aggressive policy is bearing fruit, saying dozens of countries have already opened trade negotiations to secure a deal before the 90-day pause ends.

title: Why don’t we learn history’s lessons? - (Published 21 hour(s), 54 minute(s) ago)
content: Why don’t we learn history’s lessons?
resumen: US President Donald Trump has unleashed a tariff offensive against every country in the world, arguing that the United States has been unfairly treated, luring away investments and jobs, and claiming his strategies are designed to rebalance trading relationships and bring jobs back to the US. Tariff offences are one form of trade war, which have been used in the past with disastrous consequences, such as the Fordney-McCumber Tariff measures of 1922, introduced by President Warren Harding, that raised the average tariff on American imports to 38 per cent, leading to huge price increases, loss of market confidence, stock market decline, and the Great Depression of the 1930s, which left 15 million Americans out of work. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) in 1947 and the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 1995 were established to foster economic growth and avoid a repeat of Fordney-McCumber. Trump argues that countries all over the world are taking unfair advantage of the huge American market with clever fiscal measures, unfair labour policies, and currency manipulation. Manufacturers and producers are cost-sensitive and will locate their plants where they are able to produce efficiently and at the lowest cost, whether it is in Mexico, China, Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, or India. The effect of Trump’s tariff offensive in a country that is so import-dependent (trade deficit of US$1.2 trillion) is that consumers will pay more and, consequently, buy less. The global supply chain involves the production and trade efforts of manufacturers in several countries. China is likely to pursue new trade arrangements with the European Union, Asia, Africa, and Latin America. Trump’s gutting of its foreign aid programmes leaves it less leverage to pressure countries in these regions to stay away from China. Some spokespersons insist that these new tariffs are firm and are there to stay, while others state that they provide a basis for negotiations. Trump’s moves and the retaliatory responses of several other major countries have effectively left the WTO moribund. Trump has slapped a 10 per cent tariff on Jamaican exports to the US. Ghana enjoys a huge trade surplus with the US, but its exports, too, have been slapped with a 10 per cent tariff. The US no longer holds a monopoly over technology and innovation. Cracks have emerged among senior Republicans regarding the efficacy of Trump’s tariff offensive. Senator Ted Cruz was strident in his condemnation. Senator John Kennedy declared that this is now Trump’s economy and if his policies succeed he deserves the credit, but if they fail, he has to accept the blame. Elon Musk, through a social media post by his brother, inveighed against the tariff measures and declared that its chief architect, Peter Navarro, despite his Harvard PhD, had not ever built s**t. Demonstrations are increasing across the US against Trump’s policies.

content: R. Bruce Anderson writes that tariffs are a blunt instrument, but if Mr. Trump learns to apply them with some finesse, they can be a godsend.
resumen: La imposición de aranceles generalizados por parte de la administración Trump ha causado confusión y consecuencias económicas negativas. "A quién tengo que estrangular si esto sale mal?" – Thom Tillis, senador republicano de Carolina del Norte, que se presenta a la reelección en 2026. title: Polls close in Ecuador's razor-tight presidential runoff - (Published 11 hour(s), 24 minute(s) ago)
content: Polls closed in Ecuador's too-close-to-call presidential election Sunday, with incumbent Daniel Noboa hoping to fend off a charismatic leftist challenger after a campaign dominated by drug-related ...
resumen: Incumbent President Daniel Noboa claimed a runaway victory in Ecuador's presidential election on Sunday. With over 90 percent of the votes counted, the National Election Council said Noboa had a 12-point lead over his leftist rival Luisa Gonzalez. Official results showed Noboa with 56 percent of the vote, against Gonzalez's 44 percent. Speaking to supporters, the 37-year-old president claimed a "historic victory". Gonzalez questioned the results, accusing Noboa of "the most grotesque electoral fraud" and called for a recount of the ballots. The campaign was dominated by worries about the economy and cartel violence. Noboa has staked his political fortunes on tough security policies. He has deployed the military to the streets, captured drug capos and invited the United States to send special forces. On the eve of the ballot, Noboa declared a 60-day state of emergency in the capital Quito and several provinces. The nation averaged a killing every hour at the start of the year. Rampant bloodshed has fueled economic malaise and swelled the ranks of Ecuador's poor to 28 percent of the population. About 13.7 million Ecuadorans were obliged to vote. Noboa's win is likely to see him double down on hardline security policies. Analysts said that Gonzalez's close ties to ex-president Rafael Correa may have hurt her at the polls.

resumen:
El secretario del Tesoro de EEUU, Scott Bessent, llegará a Buenos Aires el día siguiente al anuncio del acuerdo con el FMI y el primer día sin cepo cambiario. La visita durará unas 12 horas y no es una gira por la región. Bessent viajará solamente al país y luego regresará a Washington.

Bessent podría llegar con Robert Citrone, inversor y fundador del Grupo Discovery; Matt del Orfano, experto en economía argentina; Matt Schlapp, presidente de CPAC y cercano a Trump; y Soledad Cedro, CEO de CPAC Argentina.

La visita configura un claro respaldo a la gestión de Milei. La agenda formal incluye un encuentro con Milei y Luis Caputo, un almuerzo con empresarios y CEO de multinacionales y otros encuentros con el equipo económico.

La llegada de Bessent podría incluir un refuerzo de financiamiento para Argentina a través de una línea de crédito especial. EEUU podría analizar un préstamo para que el país cancele el swap con China. El swap de monedas vigente entre el BCRA y el Banco Popular chino es por casi USD 18.000 millones.

También se habló de firmar un acuerdo de provisión de minerales críticos, como el litio, y "tierras raras".

Otra versión indica que el funcionario de Trump podría llegar con un acuerdo de “arancel cero” para un grupo de productos. Las patentes de los laboratorios, las trabas para importar y las falsificaciones de primeras marcas americanas son el eje de las exigencias de EEUU a la hora de negociar cuestiones arancelarias.

Bessent tiene buena relación con José Luis Daza y con Pierpaolo Barbieri, fundador de Ualá.

title: Donald Trump's executive order on showerheads seems trivial but it's a subtle power grab - (Published 12 hour(s), 56 minute(s) ago)
content: It seems only a matter of time before Donald Trump uses a crisis and the National Emergencies Act to bring about a revolution in the United States.
resumen: Donald Trump issued an executive order about water pressure in showerheads. The order directs the secretary of energy to reverse a Biden-era regulation defining "showerhead," which was done under the APA "notice and comment" process. Trump's order states: "Notice and comment is unnecessary because I am ordering the repeal." The author identifies this as a direct, overt violation of the law and contradicts the very reason that the APA exists. If the Supreme Court lets him get away with it, another judicial guardrail against a Trump autocracy will fall away. Trump stacked the Supreme Court in his first term. On April 2, Trump declared an emergency under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977, which gives him the power to bypass Congress for an emergency "originating outside the United States". The "emergency" that allowed him to up-end the global trading system and end 80 years of US-led stability is merely the existence of trade deficits. For emergencies that originate within the US, the National Emergencies Act of 1976 gives the US president extraordinary powers. There are 136 distinct powers delegated by Congress in the event of an emergency; only 13 require a declaration by Congress at the time. The US has become a gangster state.

title: China y EEUU, ¿duelo por aranceles… o por la hegemonía? - (Published 20 hour(s), 23 minute(s) ago)
content: Qué busca Donald Trump con los aranceles a China. El detrás de la guerra comercial. Qué pasa con América Latina.
resumen:
El 13 de abril de 2025, Estados Unidos quedó frente a frente con China. Una semana después de imponer “aranceles recíprocos” a los productos de 180 países, el mandatario estadounidense dio marcha atrás y el único país castigado terminó siendo China con un impuesto de 125% a sus mercaderías.

Trump retomó la iniciativa del comercio global y busca reestructurarlo; impidió respuestas de los grupos integrados como BRICS o Mercosur obligando a los países a actuar, uno a uno, desde posiciones más debilitadas y quedó en un duelo frente a frente con la principal rival de EEUU: China.

El economista Gustavo Girado, director del posgrado sobre China contemporánea de la Universidad Nacional de Lanús, analizó que la disputa no es solo económica sino por la hegemonía.

La empresa Apple transportó de urgencia 600 toneladas de iPhones desde la India a EEUU y otro cargamento similar desde China para eludir los aranceles.

La especialista en Asuntos Asiáticos del CARI, Lía Rodriguez de la Vega, explicó que los sectores más afectados en India serían: a) los productos farmacéuticos; b) los textiles y las prendas de vestir; c) los productos agrícolas; d) los automóviles y sus componentes y e) los componentes informáticos y electrónicos.

En 2023, EEUU e India lanzaron una Iniciativa sobre Tecnologías Críticas y Emergentes, para profundizar la cooperación en IA, tecnología cuántica, ciberespacio, 6G, biotecnología, semiconductores, defensa y espacio.

El gobierno del primer ministro Narendra Modi se reunió en febrero con Trump en la Casa Blanca y está trabajando en un acuerdo bilateral de comercio.

El presidente Lula da Silva dijo que Brasil está llevando a cabo una estrategia en al menos dos frentes: negociar con Washington la tarifa del 10%, y mantener contactos políticos y diplomáticos con países de América Latina y, en particular, con China.

En la IX cumbre de la Comunidad de Estados Latinoamericanos y Caribeños (CELAC), se dio una declaración conjunta de repudio a las medidas económicas y antimigrantes de Trump, apoyada por 31 de los 33 mandatarios de la CELAC, con Argentina y Paraguay rechazándola.

Se dio un encuentro bilateral, al margen de la cumbre, de Lula y la presidenta de México, Claudia Sheinbaum.

title: China puts officials on wartime footing as Trump’s tariff tantrums stir Cold War tensions - (Published 20 hour(s), 56 minute(s) ago)
content: Trump stunned the world with massive tariffs that he said would prevent countries like China from “ripping off” the US. Chinese leader Xi Jinping ditched official caution and issued a patriotic ...
resumen:
On April 2, Trump announced massive tariffs to prevent countries like China from “ripping off” the US.

Beijing has placed civilian officials on “wartime footing” and launched a global diplomatic offensive in response to U.S. President Donald Trump’s latest trade salvos.

Foreign and commerce ministry staff have reportedly been told to cancel vacations and remain on standby 24/7, while propaganda departments are circulating defiant messaging, including archival footage of Mao Zedong vowing never to yield.

The move follows Trump’s steep tariff hikes and marks a sharp shift from China’s previous efforts to de-escalate the dispute through compromise.

Bureaucrats in the foreign affairs and commerce ministries have reportedly been told to cancel vacations and stay on-call 24/7, while propaganda officials have spearheaded efforts to frame the response with defiant messaging including videos of Mao Zedong vowing never to yield, Reuters reported, citing multiple sources familiar with the strategy.

Beijing has now ramped up retaliatory tariffs and is reaching out to other nations targeted by US trade policy including European allies, Japan and South Korea, urging a coordinated response.

The United States has escalated its trade conflict with China dramatically, raising tariffs to 145% in response to what President Donald Trump labelled as Beijing’s “unfair trade practices.”

China retaliated with its own 125% tariffs.

A spokesperson for China’s embassy in Washington said in response to Reuters’ questions that Beijing did not want to fight trade wars “but is not scared of them.”

After the initial Chinese retaliation, Trump said: “China played it wrong, they panicked – the one thing they cannot afford to do!”

China’s foreign ministry has summoned many of the heads of its overseas missions back to Beijing for a special meeting held this week to coordinate the response, according to two Beijing-based diplomats.

China has also sent formal letters to government officials of other countries pressured by Trump to engage in trade negotiations.

China has approached some G20 governments with wording for a joint declaration voicing support for the multilateral trading system, an EU diplomat told Reuters.

Chinese officials also published on Musk’s X platform a clip of Chairman Mao giving a speech in 1953.

In the clip, Mao says peace is up to the Americans. “No matter how long this war is going to last, we’ll never yield,” he said. “We’ll fight until we completely triumph.”

title: US-China trade war: How India can turn crisis into opportunity - (Published Apr 13, 2025)
content: The escalation of the trade tensions between the US and China could bring significant gains to some sectors of India. The reduced reliance of US companies on Chinese goods makes India an attractive al ...
resumen:
The escalation of trade tensions between the US and China could bring significant gains to some sectors of India. The reduced reliance of US companies on Chinese goods makes India an attractive alternative. India being cautiously positioned amidst the US-China trade tensions faces both risks and opportunities.

The White House clarified that the levies on Chinese imports stand at 145 per cent—the 125 per cent tariff announced by President Donald Trump is in addition to the two hikes of 10 per cent post-Trump taking office. In 2023, China exported $463 billion in goods and services to the US, whereas the US export to China was $199 billion. The US imports from China include mobile phones worth $64.1 billion, computers and accessories worth $50.5 billion, electric and industrial equipment worth $46.2 billion, sporting and gaming goods worth $30.8 billion, car parts worth $15.5 billion, etc, and exports from the US to China include soybeans worth $12.8 billion, aircraft and parts worth $11.5 billion, pharmaceuticals worth $10 billion, semiconductors worth $99 billion, industrial machines worth $7.4 billion, crude oil and liquid and natural gases worth $12.1 billion, etc. The consequential trade deficit between the US and China was $295 billion. The Trump administration has exempted smartphones, computers and other electronics from its ‘reciprocal’ tariffs.

The manufacturing sector of India, particularly electronics, may face vulnerability due to its heavy reliance on Chinese goods. India, despite being the global leader in pharmaceuticals, heavily relies on China for raw materials. As much as 70 per cent of the raw material for the pharmaceutical industry of India, including antibiotics, vitamins, and paracetamol, comes from China. The automakers and steel producers of India may also face supply chain pressure due to potential Chinese dumping threatening local prices. China is the world’s largest exporter of steel, amounting to $88.3 billion. The redirections of cheap Chinese textiles to India would threaten India’s textile hubs like Tripura and Surat.

India is a leading supplier of generic drugs, accounting for around 20 per cent of the global supply of generic medicines. The American companies withdrawing from China would prefer India as their production hub due to the competitive labour cost compared to China. The US restriction on semiconductor exports to China would push firms to invest in India. In 2023 AMD has committed to investing $400 million in India, and Applied Materials, Inc., has announced its intention to build a collaborative engineering centre in Bangalore, India. Similarly, if China reduces importing US goods, India could step in to supply commodities like soybeans and cotton to China.

Xi Jinping’s ‘dragon-elephant tango’ message to President Draupadi Murmu reflects a strategic but friendly gesture from China. India and the US, through a technological partnership in the form of iCET (India-US Critical and Emerging Technology), aim to enhance national security and advance economic development.

If the tariff standoff remains consistent, the concern of electronics import reliance could be addressed with faster PLI (Production Linked Incentive) scheme execution. The Pharma API dependence could be reduced by boosting domestic API (Active Pharmaceutical Ingredient) production via PLI. The issue of textile, steel, and auto part dumping would have to be tackled by stricter anti-dumping duties and local sourcing mandates vis-à-vis incentivising synthetic fibre production in India.

India can either reduce supply chain dependency on China by taking critical policy action for the next 2-3 years or face prolonged supply chain pain.

title: Global trade dynamics amid US-China tariff war - (Published 13 hour(s), 32 minute(s) ago)
content: The impact of Trump’s “reciprocal” tariffs (TRT) remains uncertain, but it has undeniably divided the world into three distinct blocs: the US, China, and the rest of the world (ROW) -- excluding ...
resumen: The impact of Trump's "reciprocal" tariffs (TRT) has divided the world into three blocs: the US, China, and the rest of the world (ROW), excluding Canada and Mexico. The US and China are in a tariff war. The bilateral trade in goods between the US and China faces the risk of being severed due to steep tariffs: a combined 125 percent plus 20 percent by the US against China, and a retaliatory 125 percent by China effective April 12, alongside the 15 percent tariff it enacted on March 10, 2025. Exports from alternative sources in the ROW are subject to a 10 percent TRT, but China imposes no equivalent tariff on them. The 10 percent TRT on countries outside the US and China is set to remain in effect for at least 90 days following the pause on April 10, 2025. In 2024, merchandise trade between the US and China totalled $583 billion, with $144 billion in US exports to China and $439 billion in imports from China to the US. China's share in US imports is forecasted to decrease from 14 percent to 4 percent (The Budget Lab, April 10, 2025), potentially creating approximately $167 billion in export opportunities for other nations to the US. China's exports to the US are predominantly machinery, electronics and telecommunications equipment, clothing, textiles and footwear. In 2024, Chinese imports from the US accounted for 5.5 percent of their total imports. If this share decreases in proportion to the decline projected in the US, it could drop to 1.5 percent, thereby generating $105 billion in export opportunities for other countries to China. US exports to China encompass a wide range of products, including electronics, machinery, nuclear reactors, agricultural goods, oil, vehicles, plastics, pharmaceutical products, perfumes, toiletries, and cosmetics. The estimates are partially invalidated by the exemption from TRT granted to smartphones, semiconductors, chips, laptops, computer monitors and various electronic parts, but the exemption does not include the 20 percent tariff on Chinese goods for China's alleged role in the fentanyl trade. Under the TRT regime, the US and China will seek identical goods or close substitutes from third countries. The wide gap between the US tariffs -- 10 percent TRT plus pre-exiting tariffs on most countries (total 25 percent in case of Bangladesh for instance) and 145 percent on Chinese goods except high tech items -- makes other countries particularly appealing during the current TRT regime. While a reduction in the 10 percent TRT is possible after the 90-day period, the ongoing tit-for-tat tariffs between the US and China are likely to persist beyond this timeframe. Fresh trade and investment opportunities will arise in sectors like textiles, footwear, machinery, and other categories within the broader US-China trade spectrum. US garment and footwear importers can establish partnerships with companies in alternative locations. US companies catering to Chinese consumers and producers often maintain production capacities outside the US. The ongoing trade war between the US and China may offer a modest boost to growth in the ROW, even as it dampens real GDP growth in both the US and China. Over the long term, not accounting for the latest exemptions, their economies were projected to shrink by 0.6 percent each, while the ROW could see a slight 0.07 percent increase in growth (The Budget Lab, ibid). Bangladesh, in particular, stands to benefit significantly, as US consumers face price hikes of 64 percent for apparel and 44 percent for textiles (The Budget Lab, ibid). The outcomes of ROW negotiations with the US over the next 90 days will be closely monitored by the Chinese government and global businesses.

title: Here’s How Trump Plans to Take Control of Greenland - (Published 13 hour(s), 20 minute(s) ago)
content: Donald Trump’s plan to acquire Greenland is very real, and it apparently involves convincing the country to hand itself over to U.S. control.
resumen:
Donald Trump's plan to acquire Greenland involves convincing the country to hand itself over to U.S. control. The White House National Security Council has met "several times" to make Trump’s desires for the arctic island a reality. The effort is driven by a massive P.R. campaign consisting of spending federal dollars on advertising and social media campaigns with hopes of persuading Greenland’s 57,000 residents to annex themselves for America.

Greenland is a semiautonomous territory of Denmark. After months of pressure from the Trump family, including an embarrassing stunt in which Donald Trump Jr. reportedly convinced homeless residents to wear MAGA merchandise in exchange for food, and an effort in the U.S. Congress to rename the territory “Red, White, and Blueland,” Greenland’s various political parties set aside their differences in March to unite under a singular goal: opposing U.S. aggression.

Demokraatit Party leader Jens-Frederik Nielsen said, "We don’t want to be Americans. No, we don’t want to be Danes. We want to be Greenlanders, and we want our own independence in the future, and we want to build our own country by ourselves.”

In January, the chair of Greenland’s parliamentary Foreign and Security Policy Committee Pipaluk Lynge warned the U.S. not to “invade” the nation.

A late January poll by pollster Verian found that 85 percent of Greenland’s residents do not want to become part of the United States. Just 6 percent were in favor of the switch, while 8 percent were undecided, according to The Guardian.

In a meeting with NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte last month, Trump said, "We need [Greenland] for international security. That whole area is becoming very important, for a lot of reasons. The routes are very direct to Asia, to Russia, and you have ships all over the place. We have to have protection. So, we’re going to have to make a deal on that, and Denmark is not able to do that, and you know, Denmark is very far away, and really has nothing to do. What happened? A boat landed there 200 years ago or something and they say they have rights to it, I don’t know if that’s true, I don’t think it is, actually.”

In an address to Congress last month, Trump clarified his intention: “One way or the other, we’re going to get it.”

title: Where Trump’s deportations are sending migrants - (Published 14 hour(s), 27 minute(s) ago)
content: In the first few months of his second term, President Donald Trump has taken steps to carry out what he has previously said will be “the largest domestic deportation operation” in U.S. history.
resumen:
In the first few months of his second term, President Donald Trump has taken steps to carry out what he has previously said will be “the largest domestic deportation operation” in U.S. history. The administration says its moves — which include hundreds of deportation flights and Trump’s invocation of the seldom-used 1798 Alien Enemies Act — are necessary to stem unauthorized immigration to the United States. Experts say recipient countries are likely feeling economic and political pressure from the United States to accept deportees.

Since Trump took office, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) has deported non-U.S. citizens via charter and commercial flights, although the exact number of migrants is unclear. According to data from Witness at the Border, a U.S.-based migrant advocacy group, there have been more than 350 deportation flights since the start of the year. Some of them were military aircraft, which defense officials stopped using to transfer migrants in early March because it was expensive and inefficient, the Wall Street Journal reported. According to ICE, the average per-hour cost of a regular charter flight is $8,577 and can be as high as nearly $27,000 for a “special high-risk” charter flight, depending on aircraft requirements.

The most notable deportations occurred on March 15, when Trump invoked the 1798 Alien Enemies Act to deport to El Salvador more than two hundred alleged members of the Venezuelan Tren de Aragua gang, which the United States has designated a terrorist organization. (The U.S. government has reportedly provided little evidence of their alleged membership.) A federal judge temporarily blocked the move, and the case eventually came before the Supreme Court, which overturned the decision, allowing the Trump administration to continue deportations.

The deportations are part of Trump’s promise to crack down on unauthorized immigration to the United States. Tom Homan, Trump’s “border czar” and former acting director of ICE (2017–2018), said the administration’s deportation policy prioritizes the removal of individuals with criminal records and those who are suspected national security threats.

According to federal data, while border crossings have plummeted, the Trump administration deported fewer people in February 2025 than the Joe Biden administration did in February the previous year. Biden deported approximately four million people during his presidency compared to the roughly three million deported by his predecessor, Barack Obama.

Many migrants are being sent to third countries rather than their countries of origin. Central America’s so-called Northern Triangle countries of El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras made up more than half of all deportations in March. Most other destinations were countries in Latin America and the Caribbean, including Colombia, Jamaica, and Mexico.

The Trump administration has reached agreements with several Latin American nations for them to serve as stopover locations or destinations for deported migrants. During February visits, U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio struck deals with El Salvador and Guatemala, both of which agreed to accept deportation flights of their own citizens in addition to other nationalities. Brazil, China, Colombia, Costa Rica, Honduras, India, Mexico, Panama, and Venezuela have also agreed to receive or have already received U.S. deportation flights.

Meanwhile, a few hundred migrants — most Venezuelan — have cycled through the U.S. naval base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. In late March, the Trump administration sent a new group of migrants to the base to await deportation.

Some countries, including Colombia and Panama, have said they are providing migrants with food, water, and medical care, as well as the chance to apply for asylum with assistance from UN agencies. But concerns remain from human rights groups about how migrants are treated upon their arrival in other countries, such as El Salvador, where deportees have been transferred to the country’s notorious mega prison.

The Trump administration is also reportedly seeking agreements with several other countries, including those in Africa, Asia, and Europe.

Some recipient countries have likely agreed to take U.S. deportees because they are facing economic and political pressure from the Trump administration. In late January, Colombia blocked two military aircraft carrying U.S. deportees from landing in the country but later walked back its deportation ban after Trump threatened steep retaliatory tariffs on Colombian imports.

Domestically, the Trump administration’s deportation agenda has faced pushback. Legal experts say the White House’s policies lack transparency and they have questioned the administration’s authority to deport migrants without due process, while several rights groups have filed lawsuits. In April, the Trump administration said in a legal filing that it made an “administrative error” in transferring a Maryland man to prison in his home country of El Salvador the month prior, but that it could not ensure his return given he is no longer in U.S. custody.

title: Nicaragua también denuncia que no hubo consenso en la declaración de la Cumbre de la Celac - (Published Apr 13, 2025)
content: Nicaragua denunció este jueves que «no hubo consenso» en la declaración final de la IX Cumbre de Jefes de Estado y de Gobierno de la Comunidad de Estados Latinoamericanos y Caribeños (Celac), celebrad ...
resumen: Nicaragua denunció que «no hubo consenso» en la declaración final de la IX Cumbre de Jefes de Estado y de Gobierno de la Comunidad de Estados Latinoamericanos y Caribeños (Celac), celebrada en Honduras. El Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores de Nicaragua informó que coincidía con Argentina y Paraguay. El canciller nicaragüense, Valdrack Jaentschke, delegado por Nicaragua a ese cónclave, indicó que una declaración de esta Cumbre debe referirse a las consecuencias de las políticas arancelarias decretadas por los Estados Unidos contra el Mundo, y acordar acciones y medidas comunes para enfrentar sus consecuencias. Jaentschke también dijo que una declaración de la Celac debe incluir la solidaridad con los migrantes y exigir un trato digno para quienes son retornados a sus patrias. La ‘Declaración de Tegucigalpa’ fue emitida al cabo de la IX Cumbre de Jefes de Estado y de Gobierno de la Celac, celebrada en Honduras, a la que los copresidentes nicaragüenses Daniel Ortega y Rosario Murillo, no asistieron. El Gobierno de Honduras, a cargo de la Presidencia pro témpore de la Celac, emitió la declaración bajo el argumento de que el texto contaba con el «consenso suficiente» de 30 de los 33 Estados miembros del organismo. Para Nicaragua, la ‘Declaración de Tegucigalpa’ debe reconocer la legítima exigencia de los pueblos caribeños de reparaciones por los crímenes del colonialismo y la esclavitud y rechazar las extorsiones en su contra y expresar la solidaridad hacia Haití. Managua reprochó que muchos de estos elementos no fueron recogidos en la propuesta de Declaración. El Gobierno nicaragüense rechazó la «imposición antojadiza de aranceles» por parte de Estados Unidos, que estableció una tarifa mínima de 10 % para decenas de países y otro gravamen adicional para los que Washington considera como «peores infractores», y en que en el caso de Nicaragua es de 18 %. Nicaragua condenó la criminalización de los migrantes, así como el trato que están recibiendo, por parte del Gobierno de Donald Trump. El canciller Jaentschke criticó «la actitud de unos cuantos países que actúan con el propósito de reducir y diluir los principios, acervos y rica historia de nuestra Celac». Nicaragua respaldaba la propuesta que la Presidencia Pro-Tempore presentó como proyecto de declaración hace un mes. Para Nicaragua, la declaración también debía expresar el firme rechazo de la Celac «a las agresiones y el bloqueo impuesto por Estados Unidos desde 1962 en contra de la hermana República de Cuba», y la solidaridad con Venezuela. La cumbre de la Celac contó con la presencia, entre otros, del presidente de Colombia, Gustavo Petro; de Claudia Sheinbaum, de México; Luis Arce, de Bolivia; Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, de Brasil; Miguel Díaz-Canel, de Cuba; Yamandú Orsi, de Uruguay; y Bernardo Arévalo, de Guatemala.

title: Economista advierte déficit comercial es una presión para la deuda - (Published Apr 13, 2025)
content: Luis H. Vargas cree que el endeudamiento externo del país obedece al gran déficit comercial del país frente a sus principales socios comerciales de Estados Unidos Unidos y China.
resumen:
El déficit comercial de República Dominicana, principalmente con Estados Unidos y China, sería la base de presión para el crecimiento de la deuda del país, lo que pudiera ahondarse con los nuevos aranceles.
A juicio del economista Luis Vargas la imposición de aranceles del Gobierno de Donald Trump se queda corto con el problema de la balanza comercial que registra el país, incluyendo durante la ejecución del tratado de libre comercio (DR-Cafta).
Entre 1999 y enero-septiembre de 2024 el país muestra un déficit de US$62,000 millones en los últimos 26 años.
“El endeudamiento externo obedece al gran déficit en la balanza comercial”, indicó el economista que es parte del grupo del Centro de Estudios Económicos y Sociales Padre José Luis Alemán, de la Pontificia Universidad Católica Madre y Mestra (PUCMM), quien a la vez advierte que al parecer se olvida que ante esta nueva situación, China va a buscar reorientar su comercio en la región del Hemisferio Occidental.
El presidente Donald Trump, aplicó un arancel de 10% sobre los países de la economía mundial, medida que puso en pausa por espacio de 90 días, luego de un efecto catastrófico en el mercado bursátil de Nueva York.
En el país, la industria local afirma que el 10% adicional de tarifa arancelaria a las exportaciones le traerá desventaja con México.
Otros economistas insisten que el problema no radica ahí, porque México siempre ha sido un competidor natural por su cercanía con Estados Unidos, su productividad y competitividad en la región, recomendando aumentar la producción exportable con mayor valor agregado a otras naciones, y reenfocando el proceso de industrialización, detenida en gran parte de la región por el aumento de importaciones de bienes intermedios, terminados y hasta de insumos.
Vargas llama la atención sobre el creciente déficit comercial en el país.
Dice que será difícil lograr que EE.UU. elimine el arancel de 10% de forma unilateral sin que se resuelvan temas no arancelarios pendientes.
En la Oficina del Representante Comercial de Estados Unidos (USTR) reposan varias quejas de barreras no arancelarias contra EE.UU. por los países del mundo, incluida República Dominicana, aunque algunas de ellas ya han sido resueltas, como es el caso de la suspensión de la cuota azucarera dominicana a ese mercado.
Hay quienes opinan que el país quedó con un arancel de 10%, por esas barreras no arancelarias.
En el USTR se conoce el arancel de 20% fuera de cuota al arroz, un ad valorem al etanol, 18% de ITBIS al queso, y un reglamento al acero.

content: El presidente de Estados Unidos agradece al líder centroamericano su “generosidad” al encarcelar a centenares de migrantes expulsados por Washington contra el criterio de un juez ...
resumen: El presidente Donald Trump se reunió con el presidente de El Salvador, Nayib Bukele, en la Casa Blanca. Trump agradece a Bukele su “generosidad” al encarcelar a centenares de migrantes expulsados por Washington. Bukele visita Washington en medio de la polémica por la deportación errónea de Kilmar Armando Abrego García, un residente en Maryland que fue deportado por error a El Salvador. El Supremo estadounidense ordenó a la Administración de Trump que “facilitara” la vuelta de Abrego García. Las autoridades estadounidenses aseguran que Abrego García está “vivo y seguro” en la cárcel en la que está “detenido de conformidad con la autoridad doméstica soberana de El Salvador”. Trump escribió que las naciones están trabajando estrechamente para erradicar organizaciones terroristas y construir un futuro de prosperidad. Bukele ha aceptado con generosidad la custodia de algunos de los enemigos extranjeros más violentos del mundo, y estos bárbaros ahora están bajo el control de El Salvador. La portavoz de la Casa Blanca, Karoline Leavitt, dijo que Trump y Bukele “discutirán el acuerdo con El Salvador sobre el uso de su prisión de máxima seguridad para [encarcelar a los miembros de la banda criminal venezolana] Tren de Aragua y de [la Mara salvatrucha salvadoreña] MS-13″. El Gobierno de Bukele recibe seis millones de dólares por ese servicio. El Departamento de Estado ha rebajado la advertencia a sus ciudadanos sobre la conveniencia de viajar a El Salvador a su nivel de alerta más bajo.

title: Trump Signals New Tariffs on Chips, Calling Exclusions Temporary - (Published 11 hour(s), 56 minute(s) ago)
content: On Friday, the administration carved out an exception for a variety of electronics from the steep taxes now applied to Chinese imports.
resumen:
President Trump signaled on Sunday that he would pursue new tariffs on the powerful computer chips inside smartphones and other technologies, just two days after his administration excluded a variety of electronics from the steep import taxes recently applied on goods arriving from China.

The reprieve for technology companies arrived in the form of a Customs and Border Protection rule issued late Friday that spared high-tech imports from Mr. Trump’s so-called reciprocal tariffs, including those on China.

While the president paused a set of punishing levies on nearly 60 countries last week, his administration has forged ahead with a new 145 percent tax on Chinese exports, announcing it after Beijing retaliated against the United States.

The exclusions in the C.B.P. rule covered a wide slate of products, such as computers, smartphones, modems and flash drives, and it represented a major victory for Apple, and other U.S. technology giants, which rely on Chinese factories to help manufacture important components and popular devices.

On Sunday, Mr. Trump and his top aides cast the exemptions in a different light, framing them as only a temporary break while the government prepares more targeted import taxes on key technologies.

The administration is expected to take the first step toward enacting the new tariffs as soon as next week, opening an investigation to determine the effects of semiconductor imports on national security.

The approach appears to mirror the process that yielded Mr. Trump’s tariffs on other specific products and sectors, including the high fees he imposed on foreign cars and auto parts this year.

On social media, the president signaled Sunday that the scope of his next inquiry would be broad, “taking a look at Semiconductors and the WHOLE ELECTRONICS SUPPLY CHAIN in the upcoming National Security Tariff Investigations.”

Howard Lutnick, the commerce secretary, said earlier Sunday on ABC’s “This Week” that Mr. Trump could announce new tariffs “in the next month or two” that would target not only semiconductors but also pharmaceutical imports.

Kevin Hassett, the director of the White House National Economic Council, told CNN’s “State of the Union” that it was “always the case” that some of these high-tech imports would be subject to their own tariffs, separate from those broadly imposed on countries in response to their trade practices.

Jamieson Greer, the U.S. trade representative, described the move on CBS’s “Face the Nation” as more of a mechanical change, saying of semiconductors that it is “not that they won’t be subject to tariffs” but that they are being done under a “different regime.”

The Trump administration had already excluded various types of semiconductors from the reciprocal tariffs as of April 2.

Some investors and chief executives publicly praised the decision to walk back tariffs on electronics, which represent roughly a quarter of U.S. imports from China.

Asked about the possibility of upcoming tariffs on chips on Saturday, Mr. Trump said, “I’ll give you that answer on Monday.”

Dan Ives, an analyst for Wedbush Securities, said in a note to investors on Sunday that “the mass confusion created by this constant news flow out of the White House is dizzying for the industry and investors and creating massive uncertainty and chaos for companies trying to plan their supply chain, inventory and demand.”

For Apple, in particular, the tit for tat between the United States and China caused the tech giant to lose more than $770 billion in market capitalization in just the opening days of Mr. Trump’s trade war.

title: Mercosur apuesta por flexibilidad arancelaria frente a guerra comercial - (Published 12 hour(s), 30 minute(s) ago)
content: Planes ante la incertidumbre internacional tras los aranceles anunciados el pasado 2 de abril por el presidente Trump Los cancilleres del Mercosur se reunieron este viernes en Buenos Aires y acordaron ...
resumen:
Los cancilleres del Mercosur se reunieron el 13 de abril de 2025 en Buenos Aires y acordaron ampliar las listas de excepciones al arancel externo común como principal respuesta regional a la guerra comercial global, tras los aranceles anunciados el 2 de abril por el presidente Trump.

En la reunión participaron los cancilleres de Argentina, Gerardo Werthein; Brasil, Mauro Vieira; Uruguay, Mario Lubetkin; Paraguay, Rubén Ramírez, y Bolivia (país en proceso de adhesión como miembro pleno del Mercosur), Celinda Sosa Lunda.

Los ministros coincidieron en la importancia de hacer frente a los desafíos que presenta el actual contexto internacional de la guerra comercial global y, en ese marco, coincidieron en la necesidad de ampliar temporariamente la Lista Nacional de Excepciones al Arancel Externo Común de cada Estado parte.

El comercio del bloque fundado en 1991 por Argentina, Brasil, Paraguay y Uruguay se rige por un arancel externo común (AEC), con alícuotas que van desde el 0 al 35 %, pero cada miembro del Mercosur cuenta con una Lista Nacional de Excepciones (LNE) al AEC en una cantidad limitada de productos que puede cambiar cada seis meses, previa notificación a sus socios.

Actualmente, Argentina y Brasil pueden incorporar hasta 100 códigos en sus respectivas LNE, mientras que Uruguay puede tener en su lista hasta 225 productos y Paraguay, 649.

El número total de productos de cada LNE se podrá incrementar ahora en hasta 50 códigos arancelarios en los que se podrán subir las alícuotas más allá del AEC.

Según el comunicado oficial, los ministros subrayaron avances recientes como la suscripción de un acuerdo con Singapur y la conclusión de las negociaciones con la Unión Europea, y manifestaron su compromiso en avanzar prioritariamente con las negociaciones con la Asociación Europea de Libre Comercio (EFTA, por sus siglas en inglés) y con Emiratos Árabes Unidos, con vistas a concluir ambas negociaciones durante el presente semestre.

El ministro de Exteriores de Brasil, Mauro Vieira, dijo que la reunión había sido “muy buena” y se llevó a cabo en un “clima de amistad y comprensión”.

El canciller brasileño destacó que el encuentro fue clave para analizar las medidas a tomar “para hacer que el Mercosur sea más fuerte, más activo y tenga mejores resultados en este momento de gran inestabilidad en el mundo”.

El ministro de Relaciones Exteriores uruguayo, Mario Lubetkin, mencionó que el Mercosur se enfrenta a una disyuntiva entre reforzarse o debilitarse y celebró que se encamine hacia un “refuerzo importante”.

Además, describió la reunión como “positiva” y señaló: “En algunos ambientes había un escenario de tensión y la verdad fue una reunión muy franca, fuerte como tienen que ser las reuniones francas”.

title: Trump tariffs live updates: Trump will explain tariffs on electronics on Monday - (Published 11 hour(s), 20 minute(s) ago)
content: In a dramatic move Wednesday, Trump authorized a 90-day pause in the higher tariffs for most countries he announced last week while maintaining a 10% universal tariff.
resumen:
President Donald Trump said on Sunday there will be no exceptions for tariffs on electronics and that he would clarify his administration's policy on Monday.

U.S. Customs and Border Protection announced late Friday that some smartphones, computers, chips and other electronics would be exempted from tariffs.

Trump posted Sunday afternoon, that tariffs on these products are “just moving to a different Tariff ‘bucket.’”

Trump said, “There was no Tariff ‘exemption’ announced on Friday" and that semiconductor tariffs will “just be moving to a different Tariff ‘bucket.’”

Trump posted on his Truth Social platform: “NOBODY is getting ‘off the hook’ for the unfair Trade Balances, and Non Monetary Tariff Barriers, that other Countries have used against us, especially not China which, by far, treats us the worst!”

Trump’s top economic and trade aides made the same argument on Sunday talk shows: that smartphones, computers and other electronics were removed from the sweeping reciprocal tariffs the president announced on April 2 and will be part of a separate national security classification under Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962 Trump is to announce, they said.

“We are taking a look at Semiconductors and the WHOLE ELECTRONICS SUPPLY CHAIN in the upcoming National Security Tariff Investigations,” Trump wrote.

A bulletin posted by U.S. Customs and Border Protection late Friday night said the administration was exempting smartphones, computers, and other electronics from his reciprocal tariffs.

Trump said, "We’ll be very specific on Monday. We're taking in a lot of money. As a country, we’re taking in a lot of money."

The Trump administration announced that smartphones, computers, chips and other electronics would be exempt from the escalating tariffs Trump has imposed on other Chinese imports, which now stand at 145%.

White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said in a statement to ABC News: "President Trump has made it clear America cannot rely on China to manufacture critical technologies such as semiconductors, chips, smartphones, and laptops."

A White House official told ABC News that the president has said autos, steel, pharmaceuticals, chips and other specific materials will be included in specific tariffs.

The administration had earlier imposed 20% fentanyl-related tariffs in February.

title: Apple, Intel y otros aliviados: Trump deja fuera de aranceles 'recíprocos' al sector tecnológico - (Published 20 hour(s), 51 minute(s) ago)
content: El gobierno de Trump ha decidido dejar libre a smartphones, computadoras y otros dispositivos tecnológicos de los llamados 'aranceles recíprocos', incluyendo a los impuestos a China.
resumen: El gobierno de Trump ha decidido dejar libre a smartphones, computadoras y otros dispositivos tecnológicos de los llamados 'aranceles recíprocos', incluyendo a los impuestos a China. La medida se produce tras la decisión del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, de imponer aranceles mínimos del 145 % a las importaciones procedentes de China. Esta acción impacta directamente a grandes empresas tecnológicas estadounidenses, como Apple. Trump justifica estos aranceles señalando la participación de China en las cadenas de suministro de fentanilo, una sustancia responsable de cientos de miles de muertes en Estados Unidos en los últimos veinte años. La Oficina de Aduanas y Protección Fronteriza de los Estados Unidos (CPB por sus siglas en inglés) esta medida se aplicará a los productos importados o salieran de la nación norteamericana desde el 5 de abril. Los semiconductores también están excluidos de un arancel "base" del 10 % para la mayoría de los socios comerciales. Las exclusiones contemplan productos como teléfonos inteligentes, laptops, discos duros, procesadores, chips de memoria y pantallas planas, todos ellos artículos electrónicos de consumo masivo que, en su mayoría, no se fabrican en Estados Unidos. La Casa Blanca emitió un memorando en el que señala que las exenciones también abarcan los ajustes arancelarios relacionados con el envío de paquetes pequeños. Previamente, el expresidente Donald Trump había iniciado acciones para eliminar la llamada exención "de minimis", comenzando por China. Esta exención permite que los envíos con un valor igual o inferior a 800 dólares ingresen a Estados Unidos sin pagar aranceles. “El presidente Trump ha dejado claro que Estados Unidos no puede depender de China para la fabricación de tecnologías críticas como semiconductores, chips, teléfonos inteligentes y computadoras portátiles”, afirmó la secretaria de prensa de la Casa Blanca, Karoline Leavitt, en un comunicado. Leavitt también señaló que “estas empresas se están apresurando a trasladar su producción a Estados Unidos”.

title: Singapore downgrades 2025 GDP growth forecast to 0 to 2%, citing impact of Trump tariffs on global trade - (Published 7 hour(s), 36 minute(s) ago)
content: The tariffs imposed by Trump and the ongoing trade war between the US and China are expected to "weigh significantly on global trade and global economic growth", says the Ministry of Trade and ...
resumen: Singapore has downgraded its gross domestic product (GDP) growth forecast for 2025 to 0 per cent to 2 per cent, citing the impact of US President Donald Trump's tariffs on global trade. The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) said on Monday (Apr 14). In February, Singapore’s GDP growth forecast for the year remained at 1 per cent to 3 per cent. The US has imposed a baseline tariff of 10 per cent on all countries and higher reciprocal tariffs targeted at countries that run large trade surpluses with the US. The tariffs imposed by Trump and the ongoing trade war between the US and China are expected to "weigh significantly on global trade and global economic growth". The growth outlook of economies in the region will be "negatively affected" by a fall in external demand partly due to the tariffs’ wider impact on global trade and growth. Singapore's economy grew 3.8 per cent in the first quarter of 2025 compared with the same period a year ago. On a quarter-on-quarter seasonally adjusted basis, the economy contracted by 0.8 per cent compared to the 0.5 per cent growth in the fourth quarter of 2024. The tariffs, announced by Trump on Apr 2, impose a universal 10 per cent tariff on all imports into the country, with higher rates for countries deemed to have treated the US "unfairly". Singapore, which currently imposes zero tariffs on US imports, is still subject to the baseline 10 per cent rate. The tariff war between the US and China has also intensified, with China raising duties on US goods to 125 per cent. The growth outlook of the US has deteriorated as rising import costs are likely to weaken consumption. China’s growth outlook has also softened as its exports growth is expected to stall amidst the trade war with the US. Product-specific tariffs, such as those on cars and automotive parts coming into the US, also remain in place. Trump's commerce secretary, Howard Lutnick, on Sunday said that critical technology products from China would face separate new duties along with semiconductors within the next two months. MTI noted the "substantial" downside risks, such as a possible drop in consumer spending, increased costs and global supply chain disruption. The manufacturing sector, wholesale trade sector, and transportation and storage sector in particular set to be hit by weaker global demand. The finance and insurance sector could also see weaker trading activity. The uncertain economic backdrop will likely dampen capital investment spending and constrain credit intermediation activity. The growth of payments firms could moderate in tandem with tepid business activity and lower consumer spending. MTI will continue to closely monitor global and domestic developments, and make further adjustments to the forecast if needed. The ministry will also release its preliminary GDP estimates for the first quarter of 2025 in May. Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said on Apr 8 that the economy will be significantly impacted. Singapore will form a national task force to support businesses and workers in response to the tariffs. title: Incumbent Noboa wins Ecuador presidential vote, opposition claims fraud - (Published Apr 13, 2025)
content: His left-wing rival, Luisa Gonzalez, accused Noboa of fraud without providing evidence for her claims. 'I refuse to believe that the people prefer lies over the truth,' she said.
resumen:
Incumbent Daniel Noboa won Ecuador's presidential election on Sunday, April 13, after voters endorsed his "iron fist" approach to rampant cartel violence.
With over 90% of the votes counted, the National Election Council said Noboa had a 12-point lead over his leftist rival Luisa Gonzalez.
Official results showed Noboa with 56% of the vote, against Gonzalez's 44%.
Speaking to supporters in his hometown of Olon, the 37-year-old claimed a "historic victory."
Gonzalez questioned the results, accusing Noboa of "the most grotesque electoral fraud" and called for a recount of the ballots.
She did not immediately provide evidence for her claims of fraud.
The campaign was dominated by worries about the lackluster economy and cartel violence.
Noboa has staked his political fortunes on tough security policies.
He has deployed the military to the streets, captured drug capos and invited the United States to send special forces.
On the eve of the ballot, Noboa declared a 60-day state of emergency in the capital Quito and several provinces.
The nation averaged a killing every hour at the start of the year.
About 13.7 million Ecuadorans were obliged to vote.
Noboa's win is likely to see him double down on hardline security policies.

content: Like the UAW in the United States, Unifor is seeking to line workers up behind the global trade war, whipping up flag-waving nationalism and supporting tariff measures whose cost will be borne by ...

Thousands of workers at Canadian auto plants have been laid off due to the fallout from US President Donald Trump’s trade war.

General Motors announced that electric van production at its CAMI assembly plant in Ingersoll, Ontario will wind down beginning April 14, leading to the layoff of all 1,200 workers at the CAMI plant until October, with only about 700 workers returning in the fall.

Stellantis "temporarily paused" its operations at its Windsor, Ontario assembly plant for at least two weeks, idling some 4,500 workers, and ordered a one-month halt in production at its Toluca Assembly Plant in Mexico. This resulted in the layoff of 900 workers in two supporting transmission plants in Kokomo, Indiana, and at Warren and Sterling Heights stamping plants in Michigan.

Unifor President Lana Payne in Canada and UAW President Shawn Fain in the United States have doubled down on their reactionary nationalist programs.

Flavio Volpe, CEO of the Automotive Parts Manufacturers Association, has said that up to 12,000 more Canadian auto parts workers are now “off the job” due to Stellantis’ production pauses.

Under the terms of the current pattern contract, autoworkers at the Canadian assembly plants of the Detroit Three who are on layoff receive just 70 percent of their normal wages through Supplemental Unemployment Benefits (SUB).

During an EV refit in 2022, hundreds of laid off workers at GM CAMI plant were forced to sign up at local food banks.

At GM’s Propulsion plant in St. Catharines, the workforce has been cut in half and now sits at 600 workers.

At GM’s Oshawa assembly operation, some 3,000 workers have learned that GM management has announced plans to hire an unspecified number of temporary employees at its Fort Wayne, Indiana, assembly plant.

title: Incertidumbre por las reacciones que pueden generar los anuncios de MIlei - (Published 19 hour(s), 33 minute(s) ago)
content: La ciudadanía se encuentra hoy atravesando horas intranquilas debido a la espera de las repercusiones económicas que traerán aparejados los anuncios emitidos desde la administración nacional.
resumen:
La ciudadanía espera con incertidumbre lo que pueda ocurrir tras los anuncios del Gobierno nacional.

Horas intranquilas debido a la espera de las repercusiones económicas que traerán los anuncios emitidos el viernes pasado desde la administración nacional.

El conjunto de ciudadanos argentinos se encuentran hoy atravesando horas intranquilas debido a la espera para comenzar a ver las inmediatas repercusiones, en la economía cotidiana, que traerán aparejados los anuncios económicos emitidos -entre los días jueves y viernes pasados- desde la administración nacional.

Con la devaluación del 30% -del peso en reacción al dólar- mañana darán inicio una serie de cambios en la economía argentina en todos los niveles.

Dichos cambios favorecerán a los intereses geopolíticos y económicos de los EE.UU. y en Argentina a algunos sectores poderosos y perjudicarán a la totalidad de los sectores menos favorecidos económicamente de nuestro país.

Algunas de las trágicas consecuencias –inevitables- que se saben devendrán de las medidas económicas anunciadas son: un fuerte incremento de la inflación, una sobre estimulada voracidad (en los individuos y en las empresas) por hacerse de dólares –a como dé lugar-, un incremento directo e inmediato de las tarifas (porque están dolarizadas por contrato), y una profunda acentuación de la recesión en curso.

La puesta en marcha de la maquinaria económica (llamada PLAN) concebida por el FMI -y aplicada por Milei, Caputo y sus funcionarios próximos- demanda lo mínimo no negociable.

La ciudadanía solamente espera -asomada y expectante- mirando los densos nubarrones que se ciernen en el horizonte.

Cada argentino de a pie solo podrá comprar oficialmente 100 dólares por mes.

El Banco Central le vendió a precio “viejo” casi 400 millones de dólares a algunos afortunados.

La medida de fuerza asumida por la CGT el día 10 de abril contó con la intromisión de los mecanismos de propaganda propios de los regímenes más autoritarios de la historia de la edad moderna.

En las centrales de transporte –y en diversos centros de concentración de ciudadanía en tránsito- de CABA altoparlantes emitían mensajes del gobierno boicoteando al paro -en los cuales se nombraba a los dirigentes sindicales como “casta”- e instando a la población a realizar denuncias.

La administración nacional decidió sobre el cierre de la misma acometer contra el ciudadano español -consultor y asesor de imagen- Gutiérrez Rubí expulsándolo del país por… trabajar para la campaña electoral de Jorge Macri.

Trump suspendió los aranceles punitorios por 90 días.

Trump logró sostener la cuota mínima arancelaria del 10% para todos los países del mundo -excepto China a la que le clavó 165%-.

Argentina no obtuvo ningún beneficio y fue advertida que EE.UU. cesaría la compra de carne de nuestro país para dar prioridad a los productores estadounidenses.

El diputado paraguayo Rubén Rubín dijo: Cómo será de exitosa la economía de Paraguay que los paraguayos prefieren vivir en Argentina con hiperinflación que en nuestro país con superávit.

title: Milei, Trump, el FMI y la sombra de la dolarización - (Published 20 hour(s), 29 minute(s) ago)
content: La “tercera fase del programa económico” de Javier Milei y Luis Caputo es, en realidad, la primera fase del programa económico dictado desde Washington para el gobierno argentino. El dólar no se cayó ...
resumen: El nuevo acuerdo con el FMI marca el inicio del programa económico exigido por Estados Unidos: una devaluación cercana al 30%, el fin de los subsidios, privatizaciones, reformas estructurales y un giro geopolítico contra China. Tras dos meses de resistencia, Milei y Caputo cedieron y aceleraron las medidas. El Tesoro norteamericano ya pisa Buenos Aires para garantizar el cumplimiento. Washington pide más que ajuste: quiere influir en el gabinete, quedarse con recursos estratégicos y allanar el camino a una eventual dolarización. La “tercera fase del programa económico” de Javier Milei y Luis Caputo es, en realidad, la primera fase del programa económico dictado desde Washington para el gobierno argentino. El dólar sufrirá una nueva devaluación, cercana al 30 por ciento. La visita del secretario del Tesoro norteamericano, Scott Bessent, solo puede explicarse si viene a controlar su aplicación. Entre las condiciones que se conocieron hay reformas estructurales regresivas y el fin de los subsidios a la energía. La salida del cepo responde a una exigencia de Estados Unidos y a la necesidad de tapar con algo que parezca una buena noticia el dato de inflación de marzo. Este mismo acuerdo con el Fondo estaba sobre la mesa desde comienzos de febrero, pero se demoró dos meses por la resistencia de Milei y Caputo a devaluar y sacar el cepo. Durante esos dos meses las reservas del Banco Central cayeron 5 mil millones de dólares. El 4 de abril el presidente y el ministro de Economía aterrizaron en Buenos Aires. El 8 de abril se publicó el Acuerdo Técnico. El 12 de abril el directorio del FMI aprobó el nuevo programa. Esto no habría sido posible sin el apoyo de la Casa Blanca, que se encargó de hacer saber que supervisa de cerca las negociaciones a través de Mauricio Claver Carone. Para contar con Trump, Milei debe alejarse de China. El Banco Central emitió un comunicado que informaba que la renovación del total del tramo activado del swap, que consiste en 5 mil millones de dólares. La ‘renovación’ que anunció el Banco Central no es otra cosa que una nueva extensión de ese plazo, que patea hasta el año que viene la devolución del crédito ejecutado por Massa en 2023. No implica fondos frescos para la Argentina ni significa un desplante para Estados Unidos. En 2026 se acaba el swap. La Casa Blanca espera que el gobierno argentino rompa lazos con China, salga del Mercosur y le dé a empresas norteamericanas acceso preferencial a los recursos estratégicos, además de reformas estructurales, privatizaciones e influencia en el nombramiento de posiciones clave del gabinete a cambio de un apoyo que va más allá del acuerdo con el Fondo Monetario Internacional. Milei viajó a Paraguay a ver a su par Santiago Peña. Juntos boicotearon a pedido de Estados Unidos la declaración de consenso de la CELAC. Los cancilleres del Mercosur se reunieron en Buenos Aires. El gobierno se compromete a modificar el esquema de jubilaciones durante el año 2026 y también a hacer modificaciones en la normativa en materia laboral y fiscal, incluyendo una baja de retenciones y eliminación del monotributo. También se dará de baja la segmentación tarifaria en materia energética, terminando con los subsidios en ese área. Por una resolución de la IGJ Milei convirtió en sociedades anónimas Fabricaciones Militares, Télam, la Administración General de Puerto y otras empresas públicas. Se publicó un decreto que pone en marcha el proceso de venta de las centrales hidroeléctricas de Alicurá, El Chocón, Cerros Colorados y Piedra del Aguila. Los cambios en el gabinete parecen inminentes. El candidato para reemplazar a los tres es Federico Sturzenegger. Esta semana pasó por la Argentina una comitiva de quince empresarios norteamericanos. Se dividen en dos grupos: los que vienen a vender cosas, representantes de empresas de seguridad, salud y telecomunicaciones, y los que vienen a llevarse cosas, de los rubros de energía y minería. Estuvo en el país esta semana Ashok Pinto, funcionario del Departamento de Comercio para Mercados Globales. Visitó las instalaciones de Exolgan y tuvo encuentros cara a cara con los secretarios de Minería, Luis Lucero, y Energía, María Tettamantti del gobierno nacional. En ambos encuentros estuvo acompañada por la encargada de Negocios de la Embajada, Abigail Dressel. En poco más de dos meses Dressel ya tuvo reuniones con todos los gobernadores patagónicos: Ignacio Torres (Chubut) el 5 de febrero, Claudio Vidal (Santa Cruz) el 7 de febrero, Alberto Weretilneck (Río Negro) el 18 de febrero, Gustavo Melella (Tierra del Fuego) el 5 de marzo y Rolando Figueroa (Neuquén) el 3 de abril. Visitó Ushuaia y Vaca Muerta, además de IMPSA. En el paquete que se estaba diseñando entre los dos países estaba incluída una ayuda financiera que permitiría la dolarización de la economía argentina.

content: The previous forecast range was 1%-3%, and comes on the back of a 3.8% year-on-year growth for the first quarter of 2025. Read more at straitstimes.com. Read more at straitstimes.com.
resumen: The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) cut Singapore’s growth forecast for 2025 to “0.0 to 2.0 per cent” on concerns that the US-China tariff war could induce a global economic slowdown. This is a downgrade from the 1 per cent and 3 per cent range previously. MTI said on April 14 that the external demand outlook for Singapore for the rest of the year has weakened significantly, leading to a deterioration in the outlook of outward-oriented sectors in Singapore, particularly the manufacturing sector. The pullback in global trade will similarly dampen the growth of the transportation & storage sector. The finance and insurance sector could see weaker trading activity. The uncertain economic backdrop will likely dampen firms’ capital investment spending and constrain credit intermediation activity. The growth of payments firms could moderate. Taking these factors as well as the performance of the Singapore economy in the first quarter into account, MTI has decided to downgrade Singapore’s GDP growth forecast for 2025 to “0.0 to 2.0 per cent”. The Singapore economy grew by 3.8 per cent on a year-on-year basis in the first quarter of 2025. Bloomberg’s consensus estimate was for a 4.7 per cent year-on-year growth and a 0.3 per cent contraction on a quarter on quarter basis as of April 8. On April 2, US President Donald Trump announced a suite of universal tariffs, including a 10 per cent duty on Singapore. Most countries now face a 10 per cent tariff on their exports to the US, with the exception of China which currently faces a 145 per cent tariff. China raised its tariffs on American goods to 125 per cent - effective April 12.
